--- 帖子 #408 ---
Bob, you mentioned above is assuming you have not any open position yet. Correct me if I am wrong again, When we see the white, blue & red beyond 15 line, we turn on the EA. Am I right ?

Yes you turn the EA on. I no longer enter my first position manually because even though there is a good chance price will bounce off of support there is also a certain percentage of chance it wont. The EA addition to this system is what saves me some considerable headaches. Doesnt stop all the entrances that arent retraces but it catches enough of them for the system to be profitable consistently. Before I did the EA thing I found my self getting into trouble too often.

2. If price go against 1st level and went against by 200 pip, we will manually put a buy limit 200 pip away from our 1st level entry price without tuning on the EA any more ?

The EA 200 is set for 3 levels and the 150 is set for two levels. You can let the EA handle it or you can do it yourself using support or resistance levels. I will do both types depending on the currency and how I think the market will be doing. If I have the 200 EA on and I see a S/R at -180 I will enter at the S/R so I dont have to wait 180 pips to break even. If I get the entrance then I am only 90 pips from break even. The same thing if the S/R line is at -220. I will then manually put a pending order at the 220 and turn off the EA. So I read the market some but most of the trading in the first two levels is handled by the EA.

3.   So, your statement abobe "if Support is broke the EA will not enter ............ is referring to 1st level entry ?

Yes, I do not enter the trade. For instance the usd/chf trade i called yesterday took almost 16 hours before the EA entered.(See pic below) Line 1 is when I made the trade call. Line 2 is when the EA entered. The EA held out for almost another 40 pips. That is 40 pips extra profit or 40 pips of less risk on that trade. You can see by the pic what a better position the trade is now. If it goes against me I am 200 or 150 pips from my next position instead of 160 or 110. These little things is what makes trading much more successful. You multiply 40 by 10 trades and your talking some real money.

4. "If it bounces off support like last time the EA will enter the trade" when it bounce off support, EA will enter, why ? Is it because the 3x3 cross when price bounce off the support, therefore trigger the EA to enter position ?

When the 3MA line crosses the 3MA shift 1 you have a reversal or retrace and the EA will enter the trade. Most of the time you will have some kind of move in your direction. Once you clear some profit and bring your SL or TS up you have a guaranteed winner. You can see by my closes every day I get lots of small profits and one or two currencies will run. They all add up. This takes the pressure off of your trading. You set the SL or TS, turn off the EA and let it run. I live and work in China and I usually set my SL TS before the USA session and go to bed. I get up and give my report to you. Imagine sleeping during the most volatile period of trading but that is what I do. I set my trades in the morning before I go to work before the jpy session and then usually add my SL TP TS before the USA session and I am done. I just peek at the score once in a while.

If you get 3-6 currencies in this positioin, something good will happen. If my run percentage is 10-20% I dont have to sit at the computer wondering should I close or let it run. What happens if I lose the profit I have? I dont worry about those things anymore. I put the odds in my favor that 1 or 2 will run and the others will give me some pocket change. To me that is so much better than hoping my one or two trades a day will score.

I am trying to be different than any other thread that exists. I give my trades and logic before the market moves not the next day when it is obvious what you should have done. This looks like a great trade but no trader guru I know would come back and say. See this great trade I did and it went 100 pips against me. You get to see this live. I get tired of these guys who come around after the fact and say, I am a fund manager of gadziillion customers or funds and I have traded blah blah blah years, and you should have blah blah blah yesterday ............. or never do blah blah blah .......... let them come online and post their picks and let us see how good they really are. SHeeeeeeeesh

--- 帖子 #409 ---
Not quite sure what you are asking here but I will try. Once I enter the trade I now concetrate on the trade and S/R levels. If I enter all below 15 and now they are all above 85 and still have not made a profit. I know I am in trouble and will get out. You dont have to wait for R,W,B lines to do anything but in my decision making I will close a trade in profit when.

1. White has gone to opposite end.

2. White and blue are at opposite end.

3. Price has hit S/R and I dont think it will continue

4. Price has hit the middle BB band

5. Price has hit the opposite BB band.

Those are my 5 profit points.

--- 帖子 #413 ---

--- 帖子 #414 ---
Whip lash is when you enter a trade and price goes against you. We solve that problem by not using SL but reentering again at another level. So we multi level trade instead of a SL and reenter later of most trading systems. That is how we solve the whiplash problem.

--- 帖子 #420 ---
Not quite sure what your seeing right now but I dont have any signals at this time. Here is the gbp/jpy. Only the white line is above the 85, blue and red are not there yet. Price is at the center of the BB which is no mans land. I would not take that trade. You want to be at the extremes. R,W,B above or below the 15 and 85 and price be at the top or bottom of the BB bands. Then you can turn the EA on. That is the heart of the system.

Maybe you are thinking of taking it as a secondary trade but if you are new to this system I would stick to only primary trades. I seldom take secondary trades right now. If I do it is because price is at the high on the screen or the low of the screen. Right now price is in the middle so you dont take it now. The only secondary trade I would take with the gbp/jpy would be if it was bouncing off of support for a third time. I would take that trade but not one in the middle of the chart.

--- 帖子 #426 ---
Agree with both Ben and jtmoore, if you take the trade when the price is at the middle of the BB bands, then you must accept that it would NOT be the safest trade that the system can offer you.

I entered a sell trade trade on that same pair a few hours later as you can see in the attached chart below. By that time, both the white AND blue stoch lines have risen above the 85 line, and the price is closer to the upper bollinger band so there is now a better chance of the price reversing direction.

However, even at this point, it is still not a primary trade signal, as the red line is not at the top together with the white+blue lines. It is not even a secondary signal by the original manual's definitions, as that would require the red line to be almost in the middle around the 50 line.

So, I know I was taking a risk when I placed my sell order because of the above factors. Hope this makes things clearer.

Bob, please correct me if I am wrong in any way. Thanks!

OK secondary trades Eur/USD versus NZD/USD. Why I chose one and not the other. The NZD/USD is at a strong resistance line and is at the top of your screen. The chances of it going down here is very strong. The EUR/USD is in the middle and could go either way. Not as good of a trade. So even thought the R,W,B, lines are identical for both pairs, I choose one over the other. See the pics below. Does that mean the eur/usd is a bad trade, maybe not because if it has established its new high, it is a great trade, if not then it will continue to go up. The NZD/USD however, is hitting its previous recent high. I stand a good chance of it bouncing here. If the USD has continued weakness both trades will be bad. If the USD strengthens both trades will be good. If price is just going to bounce around, drifting then the nzd/usd will be good. So that is my choice. Same with NZD/CHF and USD/SGD.

EURCHF - Although it appears the pair is in no-man's land, I've turned on the EA as I am hoping it will bounce off the R line that has held since 25/09.
If you want to be a traditional S/R trader, your reasoning is sound. But to multi level these trades may not be the best move. Put on traditional SL on them on the other side so you dont have a bunch of trades going into the hole. You then can keep a couple and not end up committing a lot of margin into the trades. If the EA never enters the trades then you will be OK. I have never tried S/R trading using my EA like this. Certainly would be an interesting study.

--- 帖子 #434 ---
I understand your confusion. All levels are the same in the 4H system but in my other systems the lots increase. When you get to the 4th level in the 4H system you can keep the lot size the same or increase it. Depends what you are comfotable with. I have been increasing the lot size at level 4 so I can recover a little more quickly but it is not double. I have been trading .05 lots and have increased to .07 or .08 on the 4th level. If you use the 150 that is for the slower currencies, I wouldnt use it on the more volatile ones. So that is why you maybe confused on the recovery system.

--- 帖子 #440 ---
I should have mentioned there was the AUD interest rate story today. They raised it a quarter  point. That makes the AUD & NZD market move but not enough to go outside the range of the EAs. I  post those notices in the 60x90 thread but not here. The reason I dont is because I end up entering after the news when the dust has settled. The news sends a currency to its extremes and then my indicators show it is time for a retacement. Probably in the next day or two the AUD pairs will show up as trades. The news stories push price out of the middle to the top or bottom of the BB bands, (probably happen today) The next day or day after price will retrace and we take advantage of it. If a story is very very strong then it will run up the BB bands and we try to survive the move. When it finally retraces we get out with a small loss or profit. The currency then establishes new highs and lows and we trade it again. Most of the time the market is bouncing between two points and then spurts to the new level. There are traders who love to trade the breakouts. There are those who try to pick the trend but I like to trade the rebounds back to center. So, stay out of the center.

--- 帖子 #453 ---
Primary trades are pretty easy to pick out but secondary trades seem to be more troublesome. I will use the aud/chf for an example today. Actually this one was easy to spot. First all the other aud currencies have lined up for trades. Second it is reaching its previous recent high which was also a primary trade. Third it just had a long run of 11 of 13 bull candles so a retrace or turnaround should be expected soon. Fourth, you are almost hitting the top of the BB band. So put the sell EA on it, expect to maybe hit or get close to the resistance line and enter sometime later in the day.

Second pic is the eur/aud, same reasons but it is a buy plus looks like a solid double bottom here.

USD/JPY triple bottom. So those are good solid secondary trades confirmed by other pairs in the same currency being primary trades.

--- 帖子 #455 ---
That should not affect us much. When I worry about news stories, I worry about ones that will push prices hundreds or thousand of pips. The only ones I know that do that are large interest rate stories, sudden war and trillion dollar bailouts. The other news stories if they push 200-300 pips is one reentry, maybe 2 in my system. Well within the range of my EA. My favorite are spikes. I make money on those. Price will move up 100-200 pips when brokers and banks want to clear out SL. I just add a position and then ride the spike back down again. Many times my EA will catch it right at the top when price pauses. Usually price is moving too fast for the order to get in. Wnen it stops to reverse the order is taken and then FREE MONEY. Doesnt happen very often, maybe two or three times a year, but when it does fantastic. The next day all the traders are complaining about their lousy brokers and how they got ripped and I am smiling. I like beating them at their own game.

--- 帖子 #463 ---
Thought I'd revisit this EA since you're doing so well with it. Couple questions for you. I put the 3 linear weighted open and  close on my charts to see the actual crossover trigger. Does the EA kick in at close of candle or crossover? I'm assuming at the cross. And  will the EA initiate a trade if you turn it on after the cross has occurred?  I started the EA this morning and didn't get a trade on the NZD/USD crossover. I'm trying to figure out why it didn't trigger . Cross had just occurred before I turned EA on. I've got the smiley face on the chart. thanks.

--- 帖子 #464 ---
OK The EA kicks in at the cross however price must be below the cross for the cross to trigger. Its a 3MA So it is the average of the last 3 candles. The bigger the MA the longer you go below the line before it triggers the trade. It is not when price crosses the line but the average crosses the line. Sometimes that happens at the new candle formation, sometimes before the new candle forms. Hope you understand that.

If you are with IBFX make sure you are using the 4 digit ea if you are live and the 5 digit if you are on a demo. If you are not with IBFX you need to make sure you are using the right EAs. Also make sure you have 4H charts on your screen.

Yes the EA will trigger a trade after the cross, in fact, if you take profit it will reenter the trade immediately as long as the 3 is less than the 3.

--- 帖子 #471 ---
Spent some time with you on Skype. If you are going to manually trade your levels you still must keep the 150-200+ spread on the retraces. Cant get them too close or you are martingaling and then you cant recover because your in too deep or you commit too much margin and you cant maneuver. REMEMBER there are times you just have to take a loss on a trade and go on. In fact I teach, take a loss on a level and stay only 3, maybe only 4 levels deep. If you want to enter a 4th level, turn your EA off (go to a screen with no EA) and close out your first level. (if you close the first level with the EA on, the EA will close all the levels) Just accept that as your losing trade and go on. Hopefully we can use the new level to zero out levels 2 and 3 and go on. We are not there yet though.  There is no such thing as never losing trading. That is our mental SL when we have to use L4 we accept the fact L1 is our losing trade. Also, try to reenter once a day, dont multiply your problem. Look at a daily chart of any currency and you will see that candles are usually full. The body of the candle is almost always bigger than the wicks or stems. That means once price starts heading in a direction it stays in that direction all day. So dont fight it with multiple reentries. I enter most of my retraces at the end of the day before the jpy session or before the euro open. Once a day on those reentries guys/gals. So choose it wisely or just let the EA handle it. There is a 150 for the slow currencies and a 200 for the more volatile ones. I am experimenting with a 300 reentry on the gbp/nzd. Let you know how the tests go.

From experience 150 for the slower currencies and 200 for the volatile ones are good numbers. I am only saying if you see the S/R near these levels, like 189 you dont enter at 150 or wait for the 200. You can take the EA off of the screen and put a limit order there instead or wait until it hits and put your order  there. Because I am such an impatient trader at times I am going to try waiting until the next day to reenter and see how that works or just let the 200 EA do that because I am not home that much. I am gone 10-12 hours a day from home so I can't always babysit my trades.

--- 帖子 #478 ---
Just to give you guys some hope  Here is a weekly chart and you can compare with any currency what I am about to say. Just like I pointed out on the daily charts that candles are mainly full bodied, almost every candle on the weekly has a wick on it. Which means that it retraces almost every week at the end. If it does not then you can see that the next week you will see a retracement at the beginning of that week. So check the currency you are worried about and see if it has lots of wicks near its closing price for the week. You will see most of the time there is a wick.

If it doesnt what happens the next week at the open. Does it form a wick? that means it retraces on Monday for you or goes in the opposite direction. You will see this is the majority of the cases. check the chart below and notice all the wicks at the weekly close. If they dont then what happens the next week? I put blue checks where you can see the wicks and yellow arrows where you can see retraces at the beginning of the week. Just wanted you to know where I get the info for my theories. USD/JPY is at a weekly support so that looks good to me to hang onto the buys. If you are in a sell OH MY. You may have trouble brewing.

--- 帖子 #484 ---
Wondering how all the bailout money is being handled, here is an update. Certainly not what the doomsdayers were predicting. Right now most of these programs have accomplished what they set out to do and are being scaled back successfully with the debt being transferred to private sectors. I did not know this but the majority of the stimulus package has yet to be spent so 2010 should continue to recover. In other news Bernanke is set to increase interest rates beginning next year so inflation can be controlled and the FED is prepared to start removing money out of the market as the recovery takes hold. So the demise of the dollar is not going to happen anytime soon. The debt to GNP ratio of the USA is still lower than many European countries and nearly half of Japan which is at 200%. Obviously we are not out of this crisis yet but I have never bought into the doom and gloom of the disaster scenarios. We are not anywhere near that at this point. So read with interest. While many are predicting a decline in the USD in the future I still see a more choppy market with a much slower decline than many are expecting. Anyway just my opinion on the matter.

Corporate debt purchases: Demand for commercial paper -- short-term debt that companies issue to finance day-to-day expenses -- came to a screeching halt during the credit crisis. That prompted the Fed to start buying up three-month debt, which helped calm the market. Many businesses were ultimately able to find open market buyers after the first round of debt expired in January. Peaked on Jan. 22 at $350.5 billion. Now at $47.7 billion.
Money market rescue. "Safe as cash" money market funds started quickly losing money after Lehman Brothers' collapse in mid-September 2008. When investors started a run on the money markets, the Fed immediately moved to lend to the funds and to the banks that lend to money markets. That stabilized most of the funds within a month, and the program has now been almost completely wound down. Peaked on Oct. 2: $152.1 billion. Now: $79 million.
Discount window for investment banks. The long-time lending facility for commercial banks was opened up to investment banks for the first time in March 2008 in an effort to stave off another Bear Stearns-like collapse. The program soared in the weeks following Lehman's bankruptcy, but ended in May after investment banks were able to find funding in the open markets. Peaked on Oct. 2: $146.6 billion. Now: $0.
Term Auction Facility. TAF began in December 2007 and was the first "bailout" program from the Fed. The government lent set amounts of short-term money through auctions to commercial banks in exchange for hard-to-sell assets like mortgage-backed securities as collateral. The Fed ramped up the effort during the height of the credit crisis, but has since scaled it back as banks have been able to secure funds from one another. Peaked on Nov. 13: $415.3 billion. Now: $212.1 billion.
TARP. Banks started paying back Treasury's capital investments en masse in June, though many experts said it is less a sign of banks' health and more about the negative stigma associated with a government bailout. Peaked on June 16: $436 billion. Now: $372.5 billion.

The wind-up
Fannie and Freddie. The government placed the mortgage finance giants under conservatorship a year ago, sending them $85 billion to stay afloat. But the firms are far from standing on their own two feet again -- and the housing market has yet to show signs of a strong recovery. As a result, the Fed continues to buy up debt and mortgage-backed securities from Fannie (FNM, Fortune 500) and Freddie (FRE, Fortune 500) in an attempt to keep mortgage rates low. $806.3 billion of a possible $1.9 trillion.
Making Home Affordable. Treasury's foreclosure prevention program has helped just 12% of of the four million eligible borrowers modify their loans. The administration is pushing servicers to do more after a rocky start prompted numerous complaints.$22.1 billion of a possible $75 billion.
Stimulus. The Recovery Act is the largest federal spending bill ever, but most of that spending will come in 2010. The majority of the upfront payouts came in the form of tax relief and Medicare aid to states. Later this year and into next year, the infrastructure projects will really kick into high gear. $151.4 billion of a possible $787.2 billion.
TALF. With lending to consumers and small businesses still stagnant, the government offered to provide up to $1 trillion in financing to private investors to buy up securities backed by consumer and small business loans. Buyers aren't exactly breaking down the door yet, but the Fed extended the program and hopes to attract more support.$36.3 billion of a possible $1 trillion. http://i.cdn.turner.com/money/images/bug.gif

--- 帖子 #491 ---
I have posted the 2nd edition which replaces all the downloads of the 1st edition. The 2nd edition folder contains all the files and folders needed for the system. I want to thank the 3057 people who download the first edition.
The second edition includes: Why countertrend trading is better than trend trading, (the trend is not your friend), using S/R, 40 MA BB bands, 2.4.2 recovery system and its variations, new definition of secondary trades, margin usage rules, volatility groupings of different pairs, margin usage and funding amounts, and both 4D and 5D versions are available.

If you have some of the other editions I have tried my best to eliminate the differences in screens and EAs. All the EAs and charts now use the same 3x3 cross. Because of testing I had some different types of screens and EAs and they got mixed into the different systems. For example the MACD is my own. I took the MT4 MACD and changed it for my system and called the NB MACD. It now shows the same line as the TRUE MACD but this one is a smaller code and simpler. Now all my charts are the same. Some screens had a 3x3 that use the Median and some used the open and close. Now all the EAs and MA screens are open and close. My old screens had the 20 MA Bollinger Bands now they all have the 40 MA BB shifted 1. I have the S/R indicator on the screens. I have used different colored screens for different EAs and charts so you know you are not on the basic screen.  Every effort has been made to have the system completely the same on all screens for both 4D and 5D charts. The 4D is the same as I use on my live accounts. The 5D is the same as the 4D but the EAs were adjusted for 5D screens. I have never used the 5D live so please demo and make sure it is working properly before going live.

--- 帖子 #508 ---
Make sure the NB MACD is loaded in your indicators. That is the one I am using. If you dont have it open the MT4 MACD  Hit Control F. You will get the text finder. type Histogram into the search and it will find histogram. Change histogram to 'line' and then save it to NB MACD and compile it. Then it should show up.

I have seen prices stagnate before big news stories but they still will bounce up and down in a very small range. Last month while we waited on the GBP trades the other currencies still bounced around and gave us some trades to counter the bad GBP trend but the entire Forex is doing a snail trend. I once described this like getting your small toe twisted off by twisting a wrench on it 2 mm every 4H.

I closed out my usd/cad but hung on to the AUD. The aud currencies are showing MACD divergance on almost every pair and that is a very powerful indicator. MACD divergance is when the red MACD line is going down and price keeps moving up. It is one of the strongest indicators of price reversal. Also whenever the AUD/USD has gone over 90 in the past it usually doesnt stay there very long. Makes their exports too expensive and things slow down for them. So we will see.

--- 帖子 #523 ---
I have made that mistake many times. You have to keep your spacing or you get too many lots too close together and you have a big deficit. Price will reverse but you have to wait on it, it is not predictable as the aud/usd keeps showing us. But if you keep your spacing you will get it. Keep those 200 pip retracements. Price going over the BB band more than 400 pips is very rare but it does happen and if it does, you are only 3 levels deep instead of 5 or 6 Levels and then BAM price decides to run again. Now you will need a big lot retracement to recover and that is when you can get some serious damage to your account. Even though this run by the AUD and CAD have been trying, I am not in serious trouble at this point even though I dont like the depth of my carryovers.

Bob,

This is how I've been limiting  DD so far. When I see margin use or DD starting to get out of hand, I stop taking new trades and give  existing trades time to recover. I'm currently trading (demo) .01 lots with a 1.5 multiplier and trying to get by on 100:1 leverage. DD is currently sitting at -868 with +449 banked for the week.

--- 帖子 #526 ---
The problem is the new trades often are the ones that help me get out of the hole like last month the gbp/chf and gbp/nzd trades. The problem here was I was invested in two currencies CAD and AUD and had 8 pairs all going long trend on me. The majors were just sitting in the middle of the charts and werent tradeable. In cases like these limiting the number of trades in a currency seems to be a better option than losing possible profitable trades because I am having a bad run. What just happened is really very rare and unusual but it does happen so my thinking is limiting risk in any given currency group. When the gbp had its run I was in Gbp/chf, gbp/jpy and gbp/nzd. 2 of the 3 gave me fits but I was still bagging 1-300 pips a day and that really helped getting me out of the hole. This run there was hardly any help and I ended up being invested too deep in two currencies. So right now my thinking is to go with a smaller group and slightly bigger lots. I had been trading .05 every level but with fewer currencies I am thinking .04, .06, and .08  or .03 .05 .08 for faster recovery. So 3 levels .05 is a .15 commitment and 4,6,8 or 9 is an .18 or .19 commitment or 3,5,8 is .16 commitment. I am movng the recovery levels up 1/3. I like the math a little better but the overall commitment is not that much more at -400 pips Plus the retrace needed wont be as big.  Like you I am trying some new numbers to prepare myself for the downgrade of the leverage. Keep the ideas coming, but that is my thinking for now.

--- 帖子 #530 ---
OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, gbp/jpy, eur/jpy are all similiar so choose two of the 3. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility.

eur/chf, eur/gbp, usd/sgd, hkd/usd are all slow moving currencies and will rarely go more than 3 levels. If I play the eur/gbp I cut the lot size by 1/3 because it uses the most amount of leverage and may not move much for days at a time. It used to be eur/gbp was the slowest currency around but now that the fortunes of England and European economies have diverged it can have some interesting runs at times which I don't know how to judge yet. It used to be the eur/gbp never had a move of over 150 pips in one day but the last year or so 300+ moves have happened often enough that I am keeping my distance on it. Because of the exchange rate with the USD .05 lots with it are like playing .08 to .09 with other currencies.

eur/aud very dangerous currency that go on a run of over a 1000 pips and show 0 retracement.

nzd/chf, nzd/jpy, usd/nzd these currencies trade real nice but then get crushed by strong fundamentals. NZ is a very beautiful country with few people out in the middle of nowhere. The amount of currency in use is very small and at times can get crushed by their bigger neighbors. I love the aud/nzd because the aud news will come out and it will run up and then a couple of days later the same news will come out for NZ and price will retrace back down again. Very similar economies. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.

I do not recommend trading usd/cad because they both trade the same session and the USD fundamentals can crush the CAD. gbp/nzd, gbp/aud, gbp/cad are just too volatile. I tried trading the gbp/nzd with a 300 pip reentry and still had some interesting times. Just don't think the risk to reward is worth it. If you want to practice recovery methods put these on a demo and go for it. They will give you some interesting runs.

Conclusion: This should give a variety of currencies so if one or two are having runs you don't get too deep into any currency pair. For example if the USD, EUR, or JPY fundamentals are weak and all the others are running on it, you are only battling 4 pairs at one time. More volatile currencies like the commodity currencies and the pound you will only be 2 deep at one time. This should really help in the DD. I am very uncomfortable with being as far over 1500 that I got doing all the pairs, so now I will cut my risk. Hopefully you find this helpful. I made my decisions on my experience with trading all the pairs on demos or live over a 2 year period and I think I have a good handle on their behavior and I also think I have a good balanced mix of all the different currencies.

--- 帖子 #532 ---
Most of the same principals apply, instead of trading inside out, by which I mean being in the middle of the screen and trying to determine the trend and going with it to the bottom or top of the screen, (whiplash land) we try to go from the outside in, ie. 4H system. In the 60x90 or 180x100 we start closer to the center and use the natural up and down motion (the edges of whiplash land) of Forex to take profit. It is kinda of a reverse Fib levels. Instead of following the trend and trying to reenter the dips and hope the trend continues, we use these retraces to take profit knowing, except in extreme cases, they will always happen. The farther from the median we get the closer we are to getting our profit.

--- 帖子 #551 ---
I posted this on my other thread but it shows why the 40MA BB trading system should be very successful. It also shows you how you survive with the 2.4.2 system on the 4 runners. This obviously would apply to any currency pair.

There is one part of my system that if you can handle the runners, you will be very successful. Here is the eur/jpy for the last 5 months. There are 28 potential trades you could have gotten if you just played the BB band. Enter sell on top and buy on the bottom. Of the 28 24 were immediate winners and 4 were runners. I marked the 4 runners with an x and the # of pips on each run. If you can grasp this one thought, understand it, learn to trade it, this system will be very successful for you. If you can zero out or minimize the loss of the 4 runners you can see very good profits.

Two of the runners were easy to handle -223 which is two levels, no problem, -342 which would be 2 or 3 levels. They bounced back nicely and would be easily 0 out or minimally profitable. Now the other two. If you follow my recovery system. You would take a L1 loss on each one and then 0 out the rest. The last one is the one I am in now and I have taken a level 1 loss and now am waiting to 0 out the other 3 levels. That is the plan so if this last one follows form this is what your trading could look like on the Eur/Jpy.

28 trades, 24 winners, 2 losing trades with 3L break evens and 2 trades that may or not be minimal winners or losers. I like those odds.

What looks ugly right now is when one pair is running like this, all the pairs of that group will run. The JPY is running across the board but the eur/jpy is in the worst shape right now. The others are still only 2 or 3 levels or already had a retrace. So that is something you will see and learn over time. My solution to that problem is two fold. Either use enough money to not have margin problems or use a limited number of mixed currencies to cover your trading.

So if you can learn this one thing you can be very successful with this system. Do you have the patience and margin to ride out the band runs? Do you have the trading skill to do this? If you do you can see how your losses can be minimal and your winners very successful, you will love this system

I also marked two retraces on this last run in yellow and I could have gotten out. I did think about it at the time but I chanced the change of direction and it was the wrong decision. It is not that I didnt have opportunity to escape this run I just didnt think the retraces were going to be that small. These are decisions you make that sometimes work and sometimes dont. Either way price will not keep going up forever, I am guaranteed a retrace again but this time I will take it and go for the smallest loss I can get. So if you can grasp what you see here and understand how it works you can be profitable.

--- 帖子 #570 ---
To get around FIFO IBFX says as long as your lot sizes are different you can close in any order you want. So instead of levels of 5, 5, 5 I am experimenting with 3,5,8 which is a 16 commitment over a 15 commitment. To find numbers that work try this program and get multiples that would get you closer to breakeven. The problem you have is if you only try for 50 pips off of a 200 reentry you will need to multiply by 4 to  make the third level profitable. That also gives you a  much higher risk. The deeper you go in the trade the bigger the retrace must be to get where you want to go. So on 5.5.5 each level I need a 200 retrace to break even at level 3. At a 1.6 multiplier or levels 3,5,8 I only need a retrace of 138 to break even. That is a 35% retrace on a -400 move. That is a reasonable number to expect. Fibo numbers give retracement at 38.2% so I think that formula would work. Anyway here is Frostcalls formula program that works in Excel. See if you can find numbers that work for you. I have it set at 3,5,8 to show you how they look. The program does not add the spread so take that into your thinking when you develop numbers.

I posted this on the other thread but if you get caught on the wrong side of a trade this week using the system, especially if a country makes an interest rate change, just close the trade and follow the trend. If they dont change look for a big move and then a big retrace the next day, could be very profitable. Anyway here is my note:

Well this is going to be an exciting week with prices bouncing all over the place. Interest rate news

MON AUD (expecting an increase)

WED USD

THURS EUR, GBP

Recently no news or no change in the interest rate has been very exciting. There have been big moves on currencies, some moving over 300 pips in a matter of hours, when they havent changed their rates and long trends lasting weeks when they do. I would not want to take the 60x90 into these news stories. I dont think it has enough range to handle these kind of moves when there are interest rate changes. I will not even use my 180x100 during this week. I will be using the 40MA BB on pairs not effected by the news. If you are going to trade this week do not play a lot of one kind of currency. In other words dont have 5 AUD pairs going at once. Maybe 2, same with all the others. Take your 2 or 3 favorites and trade them.

VERY IMPORTANT. MAJOR NEWS ALWAYS TRUMPS INDICATORS. If any country changes its interest rate just follow the trend. They probably will run 2-3 weeks in one direction so follow it. If they dont change there have been big moves for about a 24-36 hour period. So trade with care.

--- 帖子 #584 ---

--- 帖子 #585 ---
Finding a top or a bottom of a move is like finding a needle in a haystack so we search for it. In a ranging market Sto and BB work great. If trending then we look for the blue sto crossing the MACD. However, I am not going to sit and stare at a screen all day looking for it. We want to stay out of the trade until there is a move downward. A 3x3 is fairly accurate but 20% of the time it will enter too early. A 3x3 is approximately the same time the white sto will cross the 15 or 85 line. So the logic is I want a definite downturn before I enter and the sto crossing the 15/85 is a good place to start. The 20% of the time it is wrong we multi level the entrance. That is the theory. Once we are in overbought and oversold territory, price will move only so far before it retraces for some reason. The exception is very big news stories or a fundamental change in the currency IE interest rate changes. We watch out for those two things we are in good shape on almost every trade. If we get into a bad trade we try to retrace our way as close to 0 as we can get so we get to keep our profits.

--- 帖子 #591 ---
You can use the daily TF for signals if you wish but the EAs are hard coded for the 4H TF. If you want them changed just go into the code and change the 4H to D1 and it will be ready. Probably need to change the 3x3 to a 1x1 for the daily chart though.

--- 帖子 #592 ---
Also can u tell how to have 2 indicators in 1 indicator window?  From the custom indicators all you need to do is drag the indicator on top of the other indicator. Then you will have one in side the other. You can really have some weird stuff and is fun to play with. I put two stos and 1 MACD together to get the red white and blue lines. That is kinda what the ADX indicator is.

--- 帖子 #599 ---
There are two important things about interest rates. If they change, they fundamentally change the direction or continuation of a currency. This may affect a currencies movement for days or even weeks. As you may have noticed the last AUD change sent price up for 3 weeks straight with very little retracement.

Second there is associated news that comes out with it based on the interest rate change or non change. So even though the interest rate may not change, the currency will move based on associated news. Last year we had a change on the NZD rate that moved the market but several hours later, based on that change, the credit rating changed which made the NZD shoot hundreds of points. That secondary story caused me to take one of my biggest losses last year. That news story was not on the FF calendar but greatly affected price action. So that is why I am so cautious around interest rate changes, it affects many other areas that may not be readily seen or known as a trader.

So as you can see I am very cautious around these events. Even though most of the time the market does not move that much, it is when there is a surprise and you are on the wrong end, your account can be damaged very quickly.

--- 帖子 #610 ---
Sorry I wasn't clear with the question. Example - EA has gotten you into a trade with TP set at 50. So your trade is opened and running at the bottom of the chart with TP set to 50. At this point if you change the TP variable of the EA attached to your chart to 0, will the EA override the existing TP setting of 50 at the bottom of the chart?

--- 帖子 #611 ---
The EA sets the TP, SL, etc. at the time of the trade so if you change the EA it does not change the old trade because all its parameters were set at the time the trade was entered. In other words it placed at the server or your broker all the parameters. If you change the EA parameters that does not change the existing trade at your broker. You will have to change the original trade manually. However, if you change let us say the distance to the next reentry from 200 to 150 and you have kept the same magic number then the EA will reenter the trade at 150 since this is a new trade. Same thing if you change lot size, multiplication, etc. the next trade will reflect the changes. So if you start at 2x multiplication and the first trade is 2 lots then 2nd level would be 4 lots. However, if you change the multiplication to 1.5 then when it reenters the second level it will be 3 lots instead of 4 lots because you changed the parameters for the next trade. If you are at two lots on the first trade and you change the lot size to 1 lot and multiplication stays at 2x then the 2nd level would be 2 lots also, the same as the first lot, because you changed the parameters of the next trade. So EA changes do not affect the original order already placed but will change subsequent orders.

--- 帖子 #612 ---
aud/nzd gapped 120 pips this morning and I took the profit.

--- 帖子 #613 ---
For anyone who's interested, here are the changes needed to stop the EA from reentering after a TP is hit. Also notice that you have to delete a line and a bracket at the end. I'm pretty sure this stops reentry after a SL is hit also. Thanks to IamThat.

bool YesStop;
bool isTPSL=False;

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert initialization function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int init()

{

//----

//----

return(0);

}

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert deinitialization function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int deinit()

{

//----

DeleteAllObjects();

//----

return(0);

}

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert start function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int start()

{

//----

int cnt=0;

bool result;

string text="";

string version="VERSI INI DAH EXPIRED...SILA YM xxul_gunturean utk penggantian";

// skrip masa trading

if (UseTradingHours)

{

YesStop = true;

if (lotsi<0.01) lotsi=0.01;

if (lotsi>100) lotsi=100;

OpenOrders=0;

MarketOpenOrders=0;

LimitOpenOrders=0;

for(cnt=0;cnt<OrdersTotal();cnt++)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

if (OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber)

{

if (OrderType()==OP_BUY || OrderType()==OP_SELL)

{

MarketOpenOrders++;

LastOrderOpenTime=OrderOpenTime();

}

if (OrderType()==OP_SELLLIMIT || OrderType()==OP_BUYLIMIT) LimitOpenOrders++;

OpenOrders++;

}

}

}
if(PreviousOpenOrders>OpenOrders) isTPSL=True;

if (OpenOrders<1)

{

if (!TradeOnFriday && DayOfWeek()==5)

{

Comment("TradeOnfriday is False");

return(0);

}

}

...................................  ...................................  ..........

}

if (PreviousOpenOrders>OpenOrders)

{

ContinueOpening = false;

for(cnt=OrdersTotal()-1;cnt>=0;cnt--)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

mode=OrderType();

if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)

{

if (mode==OP_BUY || mode==OP_SELL)

{

OrderClose(OrderTicket(),OrderLots( ),OrderClosePrice(),slippage,Arrows  Color);

return(0);

}

}

}

}

for(cnt=0;cnt<OrdersTotal();cnt++)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

mode=OrderType();

if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)

{

if (mode==OP_SELLLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYSTOP || mode==OP_SELLSTOP)

{

OrderDelete(OrderTicket());

return(0);

}

}

}

}

}

PreviousOpenOrders=OpenOrders;

if (OpenOrders>=MaxTrades)

{

ContinueOpening=False;

} else {

ContinueOpening=(isTPSL==False);

}

Delete the next line and bracket

Dear Customer,

Thank you for contacting us regarding new margin requirements. Beginning November 29, 2009, any clients who have a leverage higher than 100:1 will have their leverage lowered to 100:1 as per the NFA's new rule regarding margin requirements.

We will also send out more information to clients that may be affected by this as we get closer to the deadline.

If you have any further questions, feel free to contact us anytime.

Kind Regards,

Carl Gierisch

Interbank FX

Hi Bob,

I am in EURAUD long at 1.61582. Now the price went against my position by 120 pip, and price is at the lower BB band with Red, blue & whie all below 15 line. My question is is this a good time to re-enter 2nd level ?

Reasons to re-enter are as follows:

1.   Price below BB lower band

2.   Red, whie & blue below 15 line

Reason not to re-enter:

1.   Its only 120 pip away from my 1st level.

Another question i have is the margin used. I understand you say try to stay with in 15% of the capital. Is there any way to find out how much margin I have use everytime from ibfx ? I can see there is "margin", Free margin & margin level. Which one should I look at ?

Appreciate your attention.

--- 帖子 #619 ---
Since it formed a resistance line I did an entrance there, if it had not formed a R I would wait for a deeper drop to reenter. Unless you have a very good reason you should always try to keep your reentries 150-250 pips apart. This would be an exception, not the rule, normally this would be too close but it is sound reasoning to reenter here. The main reason is it is at the bottom of the screen and to every trader in the world the screen is saying BUY me BUY me and to the sell traders it screams TAKE YOUR PROFIT, TAKE YOUR PROFIT. I would not do this reentery if price was more in the center of the screen. I think here it is a safe reentry. I hope I am right for both of us.

--- 帖子 #620 ---
Once IBFX switches to 100:1 from 400:1 it is going to be very hard for me to stay in that 15-20% range. I am going to have to greatly increase my funds and not do as many trades at one time. I will have to play with the numbers and adjust. I will answer the other part of your question when I get home but I look at my total funds commited or my total in the lower right and compare that with my total funds in the account. So if I have 500 dollars in my account I would not want to have over 100 dollars as my DD. Once it gets past the 20% I start looking for ways to minimize my risk because once you pass that 40-50% level your funds can disappear very quickly and you have no room to manuever in adding levels. With IBFX you can have up to 3 accounts. I use two of them for trading and one for reserve funds in case I need some extra money quickly. If you tranfer funds from one account to another IBFX usually does this in a matter of minutes for you. I did that in the OCT. runnup when the gbp currencies ran on me. I had to add a couple of hundred so I could use my 2.4.2 recovery system successfully. After successfully minimizing those losses I dropped the number of pairs I traded and reduced the number of trades per currency I would do. That way I wont get my funds all tied up again. With this 100:1 ratio thing I will have to keep an eye onthese accounts to make sure I dont over margin them. Come the first week of December, I will reduce the number of trades I take, lessen my lot size and have my third account ready for transfers if I need. Until I get used to trading at this leaverage I will be very conservative with my funds. It is either that or send my money overseas. I am working on some improvements to lessen my DD but you never completely wipe that problem out in multi level trading.

--- 帖子 #631 ---
This only happens about once a month per pair but I think it's an easy 50 pips when it does. It would be a manual trade along side the EA. Flip to the daily and look for the 7,3,3 (white line) to go OB or OS. When the line first changes direction after going OB or OS take the manual trade at the close of the daily candle. You could then set up a limit order to reenter if price goes too far against you. Might be something to use on slow trading days.

Hi Bob,

I am still not clear on the risk control. Appreciate if your attention again.

I read your PDF and it say, if you have $10000 account size, you trade 1 lot, is that standard lot ?

For all the trades open, usually the default SL is about 600 pip away, I understand usually we will not let the trade run negative 600 pip and get stop out. When trade go againts us, we try to min the lost my reenter and try to get out at breakeven or small loss.

This is the problem, since we never know what is the exact risk we took for every position, (we can't use 600 pip, as that fig is not realistic.) How can we make sure the position we put in for every trade is not too big ? Moreover, we tend to have few difference pairs open at the same time, this make risk control even more difficult.

If anyone has a good solution on the the risk control, would you kindly share with the group, thankyou.

--- 帖子 #636 ---
Well good luck, I have been using versions of this for about two years now but I think I have it down to a fairly final version. The success rate has been very high with the only drawback is getting caught in a long unretracing trend on occasion. Once you learn and get experienced in the 2.4.2 recovery system and minimizing losing trades, I think you will find this system profitable.

--- 帖子 #637 ---
Whenever I refer to a lot, I am referring to how IBFX defines a lot. So 1 lot equals 1 USD. 0.10 is one US dime and .01 is one US penny. If you use other currencies or brokers you will have to readjust your thinking and figures to that.

If you are trained in traditional thought on Stop losses you will have a hard time swallowing my concept of trading. In reality I dont use stop losses. I only put them in my EAs to keep beginners from wiping out their accounts because they just wont close a losing trade. I space my reeentries apart 150-250 pips apart, depending on the pair traded and the nearest S/R line. I then wait for the bounce off of S/R lines and let the retrace reduce my loss to as close to 0 as I can get it and then am done with the trade. In reality I no longer ever take a stop loss except to close a 1st level trade so I can add a new 4th level. I highly recommend not ever trading more than 3 levels at one time. From my day by day trades you can watch and see how I reduce my DD and eliminate it with very little damage to my account. It is a trading skill, I dont think I have ever seen anywhere else. The bottom line is you will either understand and learn it, (you can use it with any trading system) or you will think it is non sense to trade without a defined stop loss. I have hung onto trades for as long as 3 weeks reducing the DD until I have gotten rid of it. The AUD/USD trade in Sept. is one example and the GBP/CHF in Oct. is the other. Both of those trades took around 3 weeks to reduce to almost 0 but it worked. So if you cant ever get your mind around not using well defined SL then this will be a very difficult system for you to understand and use. From the time I started trying to trade like this to really getting a recovery to work was about a year and a half. What I posted is my final results and system, you dont have to go through the long learning curve I did. But to finish this off and I am sorry if I took so long. Once a trade is 3 levels deep and the first level is around -400 pips you would drop that first level trade before taking on 4th level. That is what I call a losing trade. They dont happen very often but they do. I think in the last 3 months I might have 4 or 5 of those. Also understand the 400 pips is a guide not a hard fast rule. I see a major S/R line at the -425 or -450 mark  I wont close that trade but hang onto it to see if it breaks that line first before closing it. Then I will close the 1st level and wait for a good entrance on my 4th level.

--- 帖子 #638 ---
How can we make sure the position we put in for every trade is not too big ? Moreover, we tend to have few difference pairs open at the same time, this make risk control even more difficult.

Again we are not out to break too many trading rules. Staying in that 20% max of your account is the goal. If all your trades are at the 3 level area then the amount traded should be within 20% of your account. If you go higher than that then changes must be made. One of the reasons I changed to a group of 12 currencies is because I went way over in Oct. of my goal to stay in the 15- 20% range. So now I think it is doable. The problem now is what changes do I  need to make when all the USA brokers go to 100:1. I may have to cut out some more pairs or to do less trades. I am not sure which way I will go yet.

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

--- 帖子 #643 ---
Note from IBFX:

ear Valued Customer,

In compliance with the upcoming NFA regulations, we will no longer be offering accounts with more than 100:1 leverage.  We are also required to alter the leverage levels on our existing accounts.   We want our customers to be aware of these new requirements to determine in advance how this may affect their trading plans and decisions.

As of market open on November 29, 2009, all currency pairs will have a maximum leverage of 100:1, with the exception of the USD/SGD and the USD/ZAR which will have a maximum leverage of 25:1.

Please be aware that this change will impact your margin requirement for any open or future positions.  For example, if you’re trading in a mini contract worth $10,000 at 100:1, you will need to post a $100 margin to open that mini lot trade.  For a nano lot, which is 0.01 of a mini contract, you will be required to post $1.

The margin call and stop levels on your 100:1 account will be:  At the 100% margin level, you will not be able to place any new trades and you will be stopped out when your margin reaches 50%.  As a contrast, if your account was 400:1 your levels would have been: Margin Call - 125%, Stop Out - 100%. We also want you to understand how leverage can work both for and against you.

Please consider your account balance and how the new margin requirements will affect you.  If you need to deposit funds, simply click on the link below and remember, we now offer no fee credit card deposits.

--- 帖子 #667 ---
That " long time to trigger" will  a lot of times keep you from entering too early if price continues to run. As Bob has said, the 3,3 cross usually happens about the same time the white stoch. line is coming out of OB or OS territory. If you want to check to see if the EA is working right, you could put the 3MAclose,3MAopen moving averages on all your charts. Then say the 3 close has crossed down over the 3 open on one of your charts. Put the sell EA on that chart and it should immediately kick in. of course you need the smiley face in the upper right hand corner for EA to be on.

--- 帖子 #670 ---
The reason I created the 3x3 EA was because I had a bad habit of entering too early in a trade. So I wait for the EA to enter. Now if you are having problems with the EA there maybe a reason. There are two kinds. 1 is for 5 digit trading companies and one for 4 digit trading brokers. IBFX demos are 5 digit and their live account is 4 digit. If you have a 4 digit EA on a 5 digit account or visa versa they will not work properly. So make sure you have the proper EA. Also, you are trading a 4H chart so trading is on a much slower pace. I have turn on the EA and it maynot enter for several days. It waits for the cross to happen first before entering. Many times that is when it opens on the other side because price has to go a ways under the line before the 3 MA crosses the line. I have some bad trading habits so that is what I use to solve one of them. Not entering too early.

--- 帖子 #671 ---
The original system was set for every level to open at the same lot size, however, I have been experimenting with different lot sizes. I have done this because of NFA regs of FIFO and to improve my recovery time on multiple levels. What I am using now instead of 5,5,5 on every level, which totals 15. I use L1 3, L2 5, L3 8 which totals 16 but I dont have to wait for as big of a retrace to break even. So far I have like this much better. With the change of margin to 100:1 I am going to go to L1 2 L2 4 L3 6 which totals 12. The formula I am using is level 1 and 2 totals equal level 3. I also am going to  double the size of  my account and try fewer trades or only trades in the top 1/3 or bottom 1/3 of the screen. I hope to not have margin issues with this until I get used to trading at 100:1 leverage. With these changes I hope to find numbers that make it safe to trade and keep my account intact without danger of wiping it out or margin calls. I hope this helps other traders with the new NFA rules.

--- 帖子 #672 ---
The close all in the scripts will close every single open trade you have on all currencies. It does not matter what EA you are running.

Now running multiple EAs. You can do this if each EA has a different magic number. They will control only the trades they entered. However, if you are with a company that does not allow hedging (USA NFA rules) then if one of the EAs has a sell the other EAs will not be allowed to open a buy trade. So this may mess up some of your entry points. Thank you NFA for screwing up my trading systems. Why dont you go after the brokers that have automatically widen spreads in their programming as you approach your take profit or stop loss lines. That would be a help to protecting traders. Forbidding trading styles doesnt protect us you bunch of dummies.

--- 帖子 #673 ---

--- 帖子 #674 ---
When you manually trade make sure you enter off of S/R lines. You can place pending orders to do that. I do very little manual trading on the original L1 entry because I cant predict an exact turn around spot. The EA at least wait until price has changed enough in one direction for a cross to happen. You will find over time that if you manually enter sometimes price will continue running for several days before it actually retraces. The 3 lines above/below the 15/85 lines or price has broken the BB band lines are signals that a trade is pending. I have used this system for several years but it was not until I added the 3x3 crossing EA that is become very profitable. I simply got into too  many trades too early and then it was a battle to get out with a small profit or loss. The 3x3 EA is your trading discipline. It forces you to wait for a better entrance. It is not perfect but it trades better than I do.

--- 帖子 #675 ---
When ever I say I am making a trade I am turning on the EA, I am not entering manually. It is rare for me to do that. Sometimes I use my 40 MA BB especially when price is high or low on the chart so I get a good entrance point but that is rare for me to do. I will manually enter 2nd or 3rd level trades off of S/R lines but I still try to keep that 150-250 reentry distance between trades.

--- 帖子 #676 ---
Yes the 4D and 5D are incompatible. Download an IBFX demo account and test it on them. Then see what changes you have to make. Another reason they may not work is the EAs are set at .01 or micro account. You may need to change to .10 for it to work on your broker. Your broker may not use .01 lots.

--- 帖子 #677 ---
ah ok - thanks for the help.

must be the 4d/5d issue, ive already changed the lot size to 0.10...anyways...all good.

--- 帖子 #679 ---
There are times I will manually enter a trade and violate one of my rules. I will do this for the AUD/NZD. I have a separate thread for that called trading the AUD/NZD successfully. I know that currency very well so I will do that. Ended up successful. What I did was add a level at the new resistance so I ended up with a very profitable trade. This jump pushed price very high on the chart and I though it was a great place to enter.

However, I want to point something out about secondary trades. See the pic below:

3 weeks ago there was a primary trade signal label #1 in white. Notice price is at the top of the screen and the red white and blue lines are above the 85 line.

Numbers 2,3,4 are secondary signals because they match the #1 trade earlier so we take them. These are all excellent trades for the same reason. It is just the R,W,B lines are showing different signals. The W and B are showing trades (above 85 line) but the red line is in the center showing that price action is ranging for now.

I also show a pink x where there is a primary trade signal but I did not take it because price is in the middle of the screen. We trade outside in, not inside out. The reason so many trend systems drive people crazy is they are trading in the middle of the screen and no matter what indicators maybe saying I have learned over time that price can go in any directions from there. However, when price is at the top of the screen or bottom, price is screaming to all the traders in the world SELL SELL or BUY BUY. I am just following predictable human behavior. If price does go against me,  how far will price go off the screen before it stops? That is my basic logic behind this system.

--- 帖子 #680 ---

--- 帖子 #681 ---
From the pic two posts ago. If you want to check out my theory, Look at all the times price ran up or down the upper/lower BB bands. Almost every time price came from the middle of the screen and headed for the top or bottom of the screen. Like anything else, it is not 100% but it is pretty close. That is where my trading style is going.

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

--- 帖子 #686 ---
Just to let you guys know. The changes to the EA in post 613 do work. This doesn't allow the EA to reenter after a TP occurs but it still allows L2 nd L3 trades to kick in. This has made my trading a lot easier by not worrying about being near the computer to stop a reentry from occurring when I'm close to a TP. When I see a good setup, I turn EA on , TP set at 50 with no worry of reentry. I take my 50 pips and run.  If trade goes to L2 I adjust both TP's .

--- 帖子 #705 ---
400:1 leverage? I think this is your account's killer.

--- 帖子 #706 ---
No no no, The higher the leverage the better you can trade a multi level system. When you trade multi level most of the rules you learned about trading are the opposite. The lower the leverage the more money you have to risk. The higher the leverage the less money you risk. You can trade my systems at a penny broker for 500 dollars at 400:1 at 100:1 I will now need 2000. That is a higher risk not lower. I never understand why people dont understand that. At 400:1 my risk of MY MONEY is lower not higher. At 100:1 you will now have to face closing positions because of margin more often now. This is not a benefit to traders especially to newbies. They now have to risk more money to learn this business and will suffer bigger losses. The cost of people's education to learn Forex has just multiplied by 4.

--- 帖子 #713 ---
I guess. When you are trained to put a stop loss 30 pips away and follow the trend it takes time to wrap your mind around  multi level trading. The guy above wrote about how he got out of the negative eur/nzd trade but he nearly zeroed the trade and feels good of getting the exit. Once you develop the skill of zeroing out trades you will love the system. If you cant comprehend or cant emotionally handle the negative trades you will never handle this system. As long as you trade with small enough lots so you can handle the occasional surprise story the system will get easier. My viewpoint is that we want to enter in such an overbought or oversold area that even with a surprise story hits, we still have the confidence that price has to retrace at some point even though it may continue in its present trend. The Eur/Nzd may still continue to trend up but that does not matter to us. Price has to retrace and there are market forces that will always cause that.

1. Banks have to resupply themselves with the currency that they just sold out on. Banks make money exchanging money whether it is going up or down. They are not concerned with the hundredths or thousands of a penny like we are. When they exchange money they add on several pennies or even dimes as the cost of doing business. I may have to pay 695 RMB to get 100 USD dollars or I may pay 100USD to get 685 RMB. Their profit is much higher than yours or mine. When there is a run up like last week they have to go out and buy the currency they just sold to replenish their supplies. So you know the retrace has to come.

2. Market psychology is on your side. When price is at the top of the screen, you just cant mentally think it will keep going higher even though the fundamentals may scream it should. A certain amount of traders are going to take profit and another certain amount are going to want to do a sell. This will cause a retrace. When the Dubai story hit the news, there was a price runup even higher on the charts causing even more people to think time for profit, time to sell. Once they are done then the fundamentals will take over and price will continue up or if there was enough sell off for it to go into a downtrend.

3. Business deals that have gone one way like company A in country B sold a bunch of products to country C now companies in country C sell products back to Country B and the exchange of money reverses the trend. If you want to see this principle in action go to the aud/nzd on the 5M chart and watch price just bounce up and down as products are bought and sold between the two countries. Those two countries have a very unique currency action because they are both so far away from other countries, and are so similar economically that it has that unique bouncing up and down action you wont see on other currencies. But it clearly shows what I am trying to explain here in point #3.

Just some thoughts.

So far, I've made probably 300+ pips in 3 weeks on this, and that is only taking a handful of primary trades, probably half those that Bob has taken (due to being in Australia and not having internet access at home right now to enter).

I think the entry points for this system are excellent. You have CLEAR and PRECISE points of entry, and an EA to do it for you! Trade management will come with experience, however bob also provides a nice rundown for that.

Im still a beginner at this system, but so far so good.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

--- 帖子 #721 ---
I just opened a SELL on the aud/nzd on the 3x3 crossover, with the triple top formation at resistance, and the white and blue lines above 85.

I know that you don't include other indicators with this system, but I also noted that the RSI on the aud/nzd is in a downtrend while the price keeps topping out at this level, and also the red MACD line lower than it was previously at this price.

To me, this adds weight to the secondary trade sell signal in this case.

--- 帖子 #722 ---
You probably have heard me say this before but all indicators are based on MA with different kinds of Math formulas. Then they use different types ways to picture the results, lines, bars, etc. So when one shows a signal almost all will show the same signal. For example when the RSI crosses the 70 or 30 line that is about the same time it hits the top or bottom of a BB band. They just used different formulas and MA numbers to show their results or how they picture the information. So that is a very good observation. The R,W,B lines of my system use MACD and 2 STO lines. MACD is a slow indicator and is late in its signals. Stochastics are too fast and get you in too early, I have found when you combine the two, when the ones indicating too quickly (the two sto) cross the one going too slow (MACD) you have a fairly good indicator. Not perfect but close enough to signal an EA with a MA cross to get you in the trade in good shape the majority of the time. After that we cover our butts by multi level trading and if price defeats that we go to the 2.4.2 recovery system and try to 0 out the trade. Combined together, you have a system that rarely takes a big loss but wins enough, often enough that if you are ever hit with a big loss, (like I did last week with the gbp/nzd) or you needed to get out of a difficult trade (eur/nzd last week), there were more than enough winners to cover the loss. That is the philosophy of this trading system in a nutshell.

--- 帖子 #723 ---
Bob, Can you tell me what might have not let this trade trigger? 3x3 has crossed and price is below cross.

--- 帖子 #724 ---
It is hard to see but price does not enter until the average of the last 3 bars is below the MA line. In other words price has to be below the MA line before the average crosses it. So if the last line is 6 the average must be below that, so if your last 3 lines are 7,8 the third number must be a 2 to get the average below 6. 17 divided by 3 is less than 6. The bigger the MA numbers are the lower price must be below the line before the average crosses it. I hope this makes sense. Its a math computation. However, by what I see from the pic price should have entered. Dont know at this point.

--- 帖子 #727 ---
OK looks like an aud and jpy crossing pairs day so let it fly. If price moves to overbought and over sold positions before tonight's announcement on  many pairs, that is a predictor of where traders think the news is going. If price moves to the center, that is kind of a predictor that they dont know. If you are into the aud and jpy like I am and price moves to the center during the day take your profits before the USA morning news stories or take half and set up a profitable SL. If price stays all day in overbought and oversold territory, you are sitting in good shape and hopefully there will be no surprises.  This observation of mine over the years has been a pretty good indicator of news price movement but it doesnt always hold true. News stories will surprise you. Like last week I was playing too many currencies because it was a major holiday week. I was not expecting price to do any major moves. Dubai news hit and bang we are deep in the hole. Anyway happy trading.

--- 帖子 #729 ---
Here is a eur/usd secondary trade. I got +38 the last time. It retraced slightly higher and entered again. When price gets close to that support line I will take half profit and let the other half ride with a tight profitable SL of +10. I am looking for a break downward but fundamental traders are crying for dollar weakness so they will reenter at some point to move price back up again. However, just in case they are wrong I want the other half to take a shot at a nice drop just in case they give up in pushing price upwards. Just a reminder, a secondary trade is when we play close to a previous primary  position. For the AUD/NZD and the EUR/USD we are playing off of last weeks primary trade high.

AUD/NZD showing a quad (4) top, kind of rare. Aud is showing weakness and NZD is showing weakness so we dont have to worry about price running anywhere. If both of these currencies go weak it will be interesting to see which one loses more.

--- 帖子 #737 ---
The whole key to trading my system is to trade small enough lots so you can use the 2.4.2 recovery system if things go against you. Since I have changed my strategy to only trade high or low on the screen I have not needed to use it. My AUD trades from Sept. and the GBP trades of Oct. were all trades taken in the middle of the screen though the R,W,B  signals were there. As you have noticed I have mentioned trades that qualify as R,W,B trades but I no longer take middle of the screen trades. So at this time, under my new theory, we may not need the 2.4.2 recovery. Either way we should stay within the boundaries of sound financial trading and not overextend ourselves. I entered all the JPY pairs also but reduced my lot sizes so if I do need to go to multiple 2.4.2 recovery trades I am able to do it.

You only need it on if you want to trade with it, its not a fully automated EA. It helps you to see when to place and exit trades.

--- 帖子 #742 ---
blessed pips -

start by reading the word file, its got all the information on the system and indicators. Once you have your head around the methodology of the system, then start getting into the EA and traing aspects of it.

The EA is only used on this system once an entry has been spotted manually. You dont need the EA to trade the system. The EA is actually used so thast you DONT have to be at the computer all the time...plus, due to the 4hr time frame used on the system, setups occur a couple of times a day rather than every 15mins or something.

Read the word file a couple of times, and things will start to make more sense.

quick note on the usd/chf. Like I said yesterday I would put a second trade looking for a retrace after a major run. ended up 0 out the trade well -15 loss, that is a good result.
