This way I have a straddle plan for the USD/CHF. However, both of my trades will be sells. I do not do buys this high on the screen. The same story for the eur/usd and usd/jpy.

--- 帖子 #749 ---
Here is my pending order for the usd/jpy. I set it just below the S line, see how it goes. You can see how in the past it was a very strong resistance line so there is a chance it wont break it now. It is one of the reasons I took my profit now on that pair rather than seeing if it would run. Take my TP now and set a pending order. This way I win both ways. If it retraces I dont lose my profit and then look for a secondary trade reenter. If it continues, I stay in the trade with a pening order.

--- 帖子 #750 ---
Henry, my understanding of the system is that there is little to no mechanism for the prediction of a take/profit zone...mechanically speaking.

If you read the word file, you will see a section on when to take profits, and what bob thinks about certain situations.

Because each trade and pair are so vastly different in terms of volatility and movement, you have to use your brain and experience on when to TP (or just do that same and bob does!).

My strategy of late has been to take 50% profit once the price hits the 40MA line, and then let the rest run from there. This strategy, however, depends on how far the price has moved and if I'm happy with the pips that have been taken, and how the indicator lines are going.

As I said, this is dealt with in depth in the word file, to take a read again and it should help clear things up

--- 帖子 #751 ---
Man I am late for work but this is just a great lesson here. I put a trend line on the screen. Another reason I took profit now and use a pending order. A fundamental or trend line trade might take a buy here but not me. Too high on the screen. This will help you understand different trading styles. They probably would laugh at an analysis like this.  My analysis or prediction is price will bounce back up and continue the trend or go to a double top. Then I turn my EA on and take the retrace again.

--- 帖子 #752 ---
Good explanation. I think I mentioned in my book several TP places.

1. S/R lines

2. Middle or opposite BB band line.

3. White line on Sto is on the opposite side of when the trade happened

4. Blue line on Sto is on the opposite side or when the white recrosses the blue line.

The most common one I use is when the white Sto Line has reached the opposite side or the next morning just before the start of the JPY session. By the end of the USA session currencies have made their run for the day and you can close or take 1/2 depending on what your info is on that pair. An exception to that rule are all AUD and NZD pairs since their markets open up near the end of the USA session. They will have a strong run there sometimes. So this comes with experience. AUD NZD pairs you will get around 50 pips, except for the gbp/nzd and eur/nzd they can run 100-300 in a day. Most other currencies you will get 50-150 in a day. As you can see I usually take my profit every day, I rarely hang on for more. That is because there are usually new pairs to trade and since we deal with retracements and price turnaround you can easily lose your profit the next day. When we trade we are getting the reversal of price exhaustion. Many times your profit will go away the next day because it will double, triple top, 1-2-3 swing trade or continue its trend. So price may reverse and take away your profit. My rule of thumb in trading is to never let a winning trade turn into a loser. I do not set my SL at 0 but put them at +10 when I move my SL up. I always want something for my effort. I cant comment on every trade but like Monday I will give you some tips once in a while. So time to learn.

--- 帖子 #753 ---
Just some advice for trading live. Wait until the New Year. Price does some really funny stuff around the holidays and can get very unpredictable. That is because by the end of the month companies are doing their books, traders are taking time off, etc. I may not even trade the last two weeks, may take a vacation and sit on the sidelines. Havent decided yet.

--- 帖子 #755 ---
The EA will do the work of entering trades for you and you need your computer on to do that. I run mine 24 hours a day but once the EA enters the trade I put the blank template back on manually do the trade after that. So my day is like this. I set my ea's to on before the jpy session. I check at lunch time and put the blank EA for the trades that have entered. I come home from  work and check just before the USA open 6-8 pm China time and again just before bed 10-12 pm China time. By then I know whether a trade is good or in trouble. In the morning when I get up before the JPY session I set my 2nd levels (some of these will be pending orders set at S/R levels) and close my profits. This way I dont over trade or let price craziness get me to enter too many trades. As I get better at my own system I try to pass on the things I learned, like the USD/CHF post earlier. Why I took my profit instead of letting it run. Why I used a pending order instead to stay in the trade if it kept going south. So that is my trading day. My actual trading time is very short, 5-10 minutes. Explaining my logic to you guys is an hour or two every day. LOL. You may ask why I do this at FF. Well, this is my real reason. SO I STAY DISCIPLINED. I will take trades I shouldnt unless I make them public. Then I will pass on some of my bad trading habits. So you guys help me stay profitable.  thanks guys. Well, lunch is over, sorry I couldnt answer all your questions. I really appreciate some of you guys answering questions for me, this saves me a lot of time and also shows that you understand the system.

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

Download the file called "2ND ED. NB 4H TRADING SYSTEM.zip" from the first page of this thread. The manual is in there.

Once you download it, unzip the file (there is a link there to do it) and the manual is there.

hope that helps.

--- 帖子 #775 ---
For some reason this problem pops up from time to time with internet explorer. There are two ways to go round it.

1. use different browser such as firefox or google chrome.

2. at the top of each page next to page numbers you see the paperclip icon Page 47 of 47 « First < 4344454647
138 http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/misc/paperclip.gif

click on the paperclip and list of all attachments pop up in a new window. Download from there without any problems.

--- 帖子 #778 ---
I expected some end of week profit taking but will have to wait for Monday. I like my position on every single trade. When price breaks it should be a good run. Though some news stories ran prices up or down a bit, more people are reluctant to take trades when price is at the top of the screen or bottom like they are now. There just isn't that much room even though in reality it shouldn't make any difference. I just think its human psychology at work. So I like my position on all of these trades. If a news story is positive price may move up/dosn some more but probably not that much.

My theory is: if those same news stories that moved price up/down Friday on the USD/CHF, EUR/USD and other pairs would have moved them more if price had been in the middle of the page. I think that is human psychology at work. Only the very ardent news fan will take trades near the top of a chart other people will see price to high and be reluctant to do so.

My thoughts for the beginning of next week are:

Price will retrace here at the S/R of the 1D chart. We can then take our profit and if the fundamentals stay strong, price will break higher or lower but we will get our retrace here first. Often or almost every time, price tests a barrier before breaking through so we take our profit off of these bounces. If there is bad news then price will break hard in our direction and we will make a truck load. Either way I think we are in a very good win win situation.

Right now I see divergance with the MACD line usd/chf, gbp/usd, eur/usd, eur/chf and the eur/cad. Those are very powerful trades on a 4H chart, SO we are in good shape.

--- 帖子 #779 ---
What is divergence with MACD?? Some traders will only trade divergence, very patient trading method but when I see one I like to load up. Here are two examples of divergence with the Eur/USD over the last 3 weeks and eur/chf present divergence. The first pic (eur/usd) price double tops (yellow A1-A2) but the MACD red line goes lower, its peak point is lower than the previous peak point (yellow A1-A2) notice the resulting price drop afterwards. Nice 470+ drop. We now have the same thing (Pink B2 to B1) price goes lower but MACD red line is going higher. This is called divergence and is a good indicator that price will change directions. Good time to take the ride and look for the head and shoulder completion. Hope this is clear as mud.  The first pic is eur/usd divergence and the second is eur/chf divergence. If you have always wanted to take a trade and hold it in profit for a couple of days this is a great time to try. I love guys who post after an event has happened this is what you should have done but I try to teach what you can do before it happens. Doesn't mean I am always right but this is a good time for a hold em strategy try. I think the dollar bears are going to buy again.

--- 帖子 #780 ---
Different brokers come from different time zones in the world. For example you can start trading earlier with a AUD or NZD broker who will open up earlier than a USA or EUROPEAN broker at the beginning of a week. Different brokers will use different start times with their MT4 so some maybe +2 GMT +1 GMT 0 GMT etc. So the only way I can answer that question is to demo the different platforms and decide which one you like best. Also different brokers use different banks for their quotes so those can be different also. I use IBFX if you want to use that for a reference to compare with what you are getting.

--- 帖子 #784 ---
You did not put the various templates, indicators etc. in their right folders, MACD sample etc. are EAs provided in MT4. You should have MACD true in the indicators folder and Templates in the templates folder. You wont find either in the EA section.

--- 帖子 #790 ---
Oh I quit trading the 5M chart a long time ago. I simply dont have time to scalp. I am a position trader now and take my position off of reads on the 4H chart. Only need to check the charts two or three times a day and I make my trading decisions before the JPY session.

The only thing is to make sure the 1H and 4H agree on direction and then trade the 5M chart in the same direction. I wasnt using the S/R indicator back then but I wouldnt trade without it now. So trade towards the S/R line on the 4H chart to make sure you are entering correctly off of them. That would be the improvement I would make with that system. I believe there is a 4H 1D S/R indicator on page 1 post 1 and that would draw the lines on a 5M chart. I think that would probably improve greatly that system. Good luck, I havent fielded a question on that one in over a year.

For example I would be trading only buys off of the Eur/usd playing the bounce off of the 1D support line. When price got to the 4H resistance I would then stop. That would probably work very well trading like that.

--- 帖子 #803 ---
Not quite sure what you are referring to but in my system if price is in the upper third of the Chart, which usd/jpy is now entering you would only be looking to sell. I do not use the alert system anymore because I make almost all my decisions just before the jpy session. Make sure the alert was on the 4H chart but I dont know why you would get a buy alert then. However, my best guess is when you turn on MT4 or you change your TF it will give you the last alert but that wouldnt be the time to trade it. In other words, too late. So  probably what you got was a sound letting you know what the last alert was which would have been many hours earlier. According to my chart the real alert was actually given the day before almost 24 hours earlier. REMEMBER the alert system is not a a signal to trade but an alert that a trade is possible. That alert would not be a trade because price is in the middle of the screen and I try not to trade there anymore. I hope I understood your question.

primary trades
BUYS    eur/gbp  (I didnt take this trade yesterday but will today)

SELLS

Secondary trades
BUYS aud/nzd SELLS usd/jpy

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

Dont you just love trading the forex, study your charts, learn them fundamentals and it all comes down to two words. SHEEEEEEESH......... and we trade because ???????????

The main dish for today is the FOMC Statement: While Ben Bernanke and his colleagues aren't expected to raise the Federal Funds Rate, there are high expectations to change the wording of the FOMC Statement.

The focus will be on the specific words about the “extended period” of low rates. Following the excellent Non-Farm Payrolls and the good retail sales, he might omit these words – this will push the dollar higher. Copy-pasting the same statement will be dollar negative.

--- 帖子 #818 ---
But i keep a third account with a large amount of cash to cover any moves if I need it. I like keeping small balances in case someone drops a bomb and my account gets hit hard. That is my ultimate stop loss. That is why I think people are idiots for arguing against 400:1 leverage. I keep my amount of money at a much lower risk. In my opinion, risk is the amount of money you have with the broker not how much you are putting into a trade versus the amount you have with the broker. If I have 500 bucks in an account and someone drops a bomb I may lose my 500 bucks but I am financially solvent as a person. They argue I lost 100% of my account, I am dumb. BUT, If you have 5-10,000 in an account and someone drops a bomb and they lose 20% of their account they think they did better than me because their loss is only 10% or 20% etc. But they lost 2-4 times the money. I live to trade another day and I can recoop my losses faster than they can.  I think they are dumb.

--- 帖子 #823 ---
I wrote this on the other thread but not this one. Beware of NZD cross pairs. They have a history of big spikes during Christmas and New Years. I dont even bother trading them. What I mean by a spike is a move of over 1000 pips in a few seconds. None of my EAs or strategies can protect you from these spikes so dont trade the NZD cross pairs. The reason is their liquidity goes to near zero during these two weeks and finding a buyer or seller can take a while.

--- 帖子 #828 ---
If you follow my rules on the 2.4.2 recovery system the deepest I go on a level is around 400 pips. At that point I only close the 1st level trade and then add a new third level trade. I dont go any deeper than that. You can do the math as far as lot size and percentage of account. When I start to hit 3rd level trades I want to be 15% or less on my account. When I get to the 4th level (remember I am dropping the 1st level at that point) I dont want to be more than 20% of my account. If you are hitting higher than that then you are playing with too big of a lot size or playing with too many currency trades at one time. My totall DD for all my trades I try to keep under 1500 but that is not always possible. When I get 2500 I know I should be dropping some of my worst trades. So whatever math and leverage you need should stay in those ranges. Except on really long runs (like the eur/usd and usd/chf are doing now) I generally stay well under 1000 on my DD. 1000 DD may sound like a lot but in reality I have seen that disappear in 1-2 days when price reverses. Even as a trend trader you could probably adapt my 2.4.2 recovery system into your system. I like it so much better than using stop losses. I use S/R lines on a 4H or 1D to make my decisions on where to put my extra levels with my spacing being around 200 pips apart.

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.        __________________

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.
[/quote][/quote]

I am looking for someone that can code a simple indicator for me. Below is the code and all I want is for it to draw the lines on a screen. Should work in all TF. What I want is the ability to fix screen size for example if on a 1H chart it will only figure screen size for the last 4 days or only the last 4 days  seen on the screen. To work in all TF that would be 4 time periods. For example 4H chart would be the last 4 weeks etc. I just havent been able to get the indicator to work and I am heading into finals at the schools at work at so I dont have time for the next 3 weeks to do this. Much appreciated if someone could do this. Plan on using this for this 4H trading method and another idea of using it for a trend following system. Below is the basic coding.

double WindowTop = WindowPriceMax();
double WindowBottom = WindowPriceMin();

double HalfWay = (WindowTop + WindowBottom) / 2;

double PriceFromTop = WindowTop - ((WindowTop - WindowBottom) * 0.25);

double PriceFromBottom = WindowBottom + ((WindowTop - WindowBottom) * 0.25);

//Draw lines using above values.

--- 帖子 #845 ---

--- 帖子 #846 ---
Showing a eur/nzd 4H screen the distance from top to bottom is 1207 pips. I will use 1200 to illustrate what I want it to do.

--- 帖子 #847 ---
The indicator will then draw lines based on percentages entered. This screen we are asking it to do 25% 50% and 75%. It could also do 20 % 80% or 10% 90%. etc. The indicator then will play a sound and post a message when the top or bottom lines are crossed. Of course some of you can see where I am going with this.

--- 帖子 #848 ---
Then in the left hand corner with abbreviations and smaller lettering it will post the information of distance from top to bottom and top to top line and bottom to bottom line. This info should help you in figuring out reentry numbers for each pair. For example the distance is 300 pips for eur/nzd so our reentries will be between 2-300 pips. Other pairs would be smaller etc.

--- 帖子 #849 ---

--- 帖子 #850 ---
Hypothetical question here. Say you've entered a trade and it goes against you badly. There have been no good retraces and you have dropped a couple,  levels using the 242 strategy. You've taken substantial losses but still no point to exit. If you look at the EUR/USD in early Dec. 2008 this scenario  occurs. Would you keep dropping a level using the 242 strategy or would you close all trades at the break of a S/R level  and give the pair a rest for awhile? Either way, this could lead to huge losses. I'm thinking the only way out would have  been to try to cancel some of these losses with wins on other pairs and bite the bullet on the E/U.

As you know the long drawn out trend run that moves slowly and never retraces is the biggest killer of my systems. See the pic below as I give the history of the trade and what I did. I think the biggest disservice I have done you guys is not do a daily on my losing streak. It should have been a good teaching tool watching me handle these type of losses. As you can see I had opportunities to take out that trade without a big loss but I get arrogant and think I can get out of any losing situation. That is not always true and then I end up taking a much bigger loss than I should have. I really felt with a 3 hump divergance on a 4H chart (MACD line) I was looking at a nice winner but it did not happen. 90% of the time that would be true but with the upcoming holidays there just wasn't enough trading/business going on to make it happen. --- 帖子 #853 ---
Excellent ideas, however, we in the USA can no longer hedge. I had developed a trading system buying a buy and sell at the same time. I would then take profit no matter which direction price went and using half of the winning position to close 40% of the losing position. I would then hedge again and waited until one position profited enough to take away half of a losing position. I would then try to trade out the last part of the losing position. It worked well in my testing but because hedging was banned by the NFA I was no longer able to trade. I loved hedging. I could walk away from my computer at any time and pick up the trade at another time. It gave you a chance to regroup yourself and overcome your negative thoughts and feelings. I could wait until the market gave me a better decision  point to trade again. Yes I agree with your thoughts and think they are excellent. We just cant do that anymore with a USA broker and many foreign brokers dont want to take USA clients now. So we are stuck for now. Thanks for the great input.

--- 帖子 #854 ---
Here is my lament about the loss of hedging and some of my thoughts about the NFA:

P. 55 post 822 I give an example of why I think the NFA are a bunch of loonies for banning hedging. I give a perfect example of why hedging is a valuable trading tool and a perfect time to use it. I don't like what the markets do at holiday times, so I can hedge my trades and come back after to trade again without taking unnecessary risks. Now I have to take some risks to protect my account. Stupid NFA.

Because I could not hedge my positions just before Christmas I lost my 1300 pips profit I had and my losses continued. I would rather have hedged all my positions and come back after the new year and kept my 1300  pip profit for December. I never would have gotten so deep in the hole if I could have done that. So I dont want any idiots coming on my thread talking about how they cant see how hedging is a benefit for the trader and the NFA is trying to protect traders from themselves. My position is the NFA is trying to force traders into a certain trading style of trading not  protecting me from brokers. Banning hedging is a benefit to brokers because now certain trading styles, like mine, have to take deep losses instead of hedging until we get more favorable trading scenarios. Sorry to rant and rave.

EGADS!!! Dont try learning my system with gbp/aud, gbp/nzd, gbp/jpy, eur/nzd. They are killers unless you got deep pockets. I will trade the gbp/jpy and eur/nzd on occasion but not the others. They really move big time and can get you in the hole very quickly. They dont like to follow the charts and can go 2000 pip moves. I dont have that deep of pockets to play them. The NZD is a currency of a country of 4 million people. It can get crushed by the bigger currencies and be totally unforgiving. In my 7 year currency fact sheet the NZD cross pairs had the biggest one days moves ever with some going over 2000 pips in one day. The Aud is becoming a more powerful pair and doesnt quite get hosed as the NZD. As it continues to grow as a currency with trade in Asia it is less likely now to do that but remember that the big 3 USD, EUR, GBP can crush any of the other currencies. Just visit the charts on OCT. 2008 and see what the USD can do to other currencies when it has super big fundamental news. Unless your an Aussie and know your own currency very very well, I wouldnt recommend it.

--- 帖子 #867 ---
Bob,

Here you go. I posted this in post 613 in this thread. Changes are in bold print. Remember to delete the last line and bracket. These changes work. I've been using them for over a month now.
http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/icons/icon1.gif Here's how to stop EA from reentering

For anyone who's interested, here are the changes needed to stop the EA from reentering after a TP is hit. Also notice that you have to delete a line and a bracket at the end. I'm pretty sure this stops reentry after a SL is hit also. Thanks to IamThat.

bool YesStop;
bool isTPSL=False;

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert initialization function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int init()

{

//----

//----

return(0);

}

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert deinitialization function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int deinit()

{

//----

DeleteAllObjects();

//----

return(0);

}

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

//| expert start function |

//+------------------------------------------------------------------+

int start()

{

//----

int cnt=0;

bool result;

string text="";

string version="VERSI INI DAH EXPIRED...SILA YM xxul_gunturean utk penggantian";

// skrip masa trading

if (UseTradingHours)

{

YesStop = true;

if (lotsi<0.01) lotsi=0.01;

if (lotsi>100) lotsi=100;

OpenOrders=0;

MarketOpenOrders=0;

LimitOpenOrders=0;

for(cnt=0;cnt<OrdersTotal();cnt++)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

if (OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber)

{

if (OrderType()==OP_BUY || OrderType()==OP_SELL)

{

MarketOpenOrders++;

LastOrderOpenTime=OrderOpenTime();

}

if (OrderType()==OP_SELLLIMIT || OrderType()==OP_BUYLIMIT) LimitOpenOrders++;

OpenOrders++;

}

}

}
if(PreviousOpenOrders>OpenOrders) isTPSL=True;

if (OpenOrders<1)

{

if (!TradeOnFriday && DayOfWeek()==5)

{

Comment("TradeOnfriday is False");

return(0);

}

}

...................................  ...................................  ..........

}

if (PreviousOpenOrders>OpenOrders)

{

ContinueOpening = false;

for(cnt=OrdersTotal()-1;cnt>=0;cnt--)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

mode=OrderType();

if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)

{

if (mode==OP_BUY || mode==OP_SELL)

{

OrderClose(OrderTicket(),OrderLots( ),OrderClosePrice(),slippage,Arrows  Color);

return(0);

}

}

}

}

for(cnt=0;cnt<OrdersTotal();cnt++)

{

if (OrderSelect(cnt, SELECT_BY_POS, MODE_TRADES))

{

mode=OrderType();

if ((OrderSymbol()==Symbol() && OrderMagicNumber() == MagicNumber) || AllSymbolsProtect)

{

if (mode==OP_SELLLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYLIMIT || mode==OP_BUYSTOP || mode==OP_SELLSTOP)

{

OrderDelete(OrderTicket());

return(0);

}

}

}

}

}

PreviousOpenOrders=OpenOrders;

if (OpenOrders>=MaxTrades)

{

ContinueOpening=False;

} else {

ContinueOpening=(isTPSL==False);

}

Delete the next line and bracket
http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/buttons/quote.gif

--- 帖子 #874 ---
Thank you Mr. Toothman. Here is another change and makes a great read. Change the BB bands to:

1. 50 post the main line with Dev set at 2 shift 1.

2. 51 Dev. 3 shift 1 use dotted lines

3. 49 Dev. 1 shift 1 use dotted lines

4. RSI to 8 with lines at 75 and 25

New entrance points for recovery BB bands Dev. 3

Measure distance from Dev. line 3 to Dev. line 2 = total pips A

Measure distance from 1st entrance to Dev. line 3 = total pips B

tpA = recovery distance

tpB = amount needed to recover

Division is tpB / tpA

What is multiplication to break even?

If distance for tpB 210 pips in the hole

If distance for tpB is 70 pips

210/70 = 3

Multiply next level entrance by 3, set your TP for both levels to break even.

You are out.

So you want out of a bad trade or you want a quick TP off of level 3 BB There are your numbers. When price hits Dev. level 3 enter and then TP at level 2. Confirm RSI above below 25/75. An RSI warning system probably exists somewhere at FF. An EA that enters off of Dev. 3 would be easy to write. What do you think???

See pic below. I also attached the template. HMMMMMMMM will study this one. May lead to new entrance rules. Scalping the 4H chart. yuk yuk

--- 帖子 #875 ---
The other thing I forgot to mention is when you see price bouncing between Dev. 2 and 1 you know you are in trouble. If you want to take a minumum loss Dev. 1 is your recovery TP for a minimum loss on the 2.4.2 recovery system. This looks good, I like the clear cut rules here. If you are in a trade and you want to break even reenter outside Dev. 2 or 3 TP at next deviation line and do the math. I love it when pieces come to gether. Again if you use Dev. 2 you confirm with the RSI being >< 25/75.

Another thought if you are 3 levels deep do the math for just one level. So you want level 3 to break even your level 1 trade and you leave level 2 to see if price breaks in your favor. If it doesnt then you will use a L4 trade to break even your level 2 but you have already closed out 1 and 3 so they would be your present level 1 and 2. I know clear as mud. In other words, if you are at 3 levels you dont need to try to clear both level 1 and 2 at the same time if your margin is tight or you dont want to risk a high multiplication.

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that much margin for a slow mover like that.

--- 帖子 #896 ---
Some were secondary trades yes. My definition of a secondary trade is a trade that was previously a primary trade but has now double or tripled top or is showing divergance on a 4H chart (they are going into a head and shoulders pattern). To me they are just as good as a primary in fact they are usually better in that the move is usually bigger than the original primary trade. What I am going to do now is add to the system with straddle trades. I have taken my profit but just in case the trade continues to run I will stay in it or if it goes back to its previous entrance signal I will try to enter at its extreme. So we see how it goes.

One thing I am working on is an EA that will automatically move the SL up to 0 and then +10 on straddle trades and also will only trade once and quit. Once I get that EA written and working properly I want to start following the trend more with straddle trades using 4H and 1D S/R lines. Hopefully it will add to our profits. I like its potential anyway so I need a programmer to help me. I know how to change programs and make adjustments but I dont do fresh programming.

--- 帖子 #902 ---
No it is part of the method, we multi level trade because there is no 100% certainty price will change at the signals. What you want to do now is ride your second level and try to break even or get a small profit on this trade. When the trade is equalized put in SL so you dont lose the break even or minimal loss and then see if the trade continues into profit. The difference between my system and others is, instead of taking SL we try to break even on losing trades so our equity curve will keep moving up over time. It takes time to grasp this concept in trading when you have been hammered with USE A STOP LOSS all your trading life. My philosophy is only take a SL in extreme cases and always try to break even. December was the only time I took an extreme loss but that was a very rare exception in price movement. Prices moved for 3-4 weeks without retracing which is something I had not seen before. So it was good I had quit trading in December. So that is the basic philosophy behind this system. Also I usually do not reenter on less than 150 pips but we are so high up on the screen I went ahead and did at the R line. If you reenter too early it can also cause problems.

--- 帖子 #903 ---
If you're using the EA to enter,it uses the average of the last three candles. I've been playing around with entering manually when red, white and blue are at extremes, price is in top or bottom third of chart and RSI(8) is showing divergence.

--- 帖子 #915 ---
an update:

Goodbye US Forex industry: Part 2
Posted by Michael Greenberg in Brokers,  Traders 0 Comments     Continuing my post from last Friday about the CFTC’s anti-Forex regulations (I dear you to fathom this 193 pages document) there are couple more points we should discuss:

1. First one is the “Foreign Exchange Dealers Coalition” manifest first published by fxstreet’s Francesc. It’s an interesting piece of paper, not solely because of its content, but also by the first ever appearance of a US retail forex brokers’ alliance – and this is a revolution, no less. It seems that in fear of the worst even forex brokers can unite. This is highly important because brokers unity is perhaps US industry’s last chance and because for the first time the brokers collectively realized the danger. This however is probably too late.

CFTC is all but done introducing the new requirements, and this Comment Period is just a bureaucratic procedure. US brokers should realize that the window to fend off this attack is long gone, and it’s time to adapt to a whole new reality – the US government doesn’t want you there, it prefers you to move to offshore locations. Unfortunately for you, these offshore locations are already pretty well inhabited by other brokers so the rules of game are much more different now.

The Foreign Exchange Dealers Coalition summarizes their stand with the following:

“The case against the 10 to 1 leverage rule is clear. The rule will be a boon to foreign forex dealers (both regulated and unregulated) who will grow entirely at the expense of retail forex dealers in the United States. Thousands of high paying jobs will be lost and the potential for tens of thousands of more jobs will forever vanish as well. Consumers will be hurt and more vulnerable to fraud. And the United States will toss away one of the most promising export industries that it has, all in the midst of 10% unemployment. There is no good reason that this should be so.”
They are spot on, but nobody in the CFTC cares.

2. The second point that most is overlooked while focusing on the 10-to-1 leverage requirement (which is crucial by itself) is that CFTC ‘proposed’ not only the reduction in leverage but also 193 pages of other requirements. In fact, it’s a whole new book of how the retail forex industry should look like. For instance:

Subject to certain exceptions (e.g., for certain regulated financial intermediaries not under the Commission’s jurisdiction as established in the CRA), the Proposal would require persons offering to be or acting as counterparties to retail forex transactions but not primarily or substantially engaged in the exchange traded futures business, to register as retail foreign exchange dealers (“RFEDs”) with the CFTC. Registered futures commission merchants (“FCMs”) that are “primarily or substantially” (as defined in the Proposal) engaged in the activities set forth in the Act’s definition of an FCM would be permitted to engage in retail forex transactions without also registering as RFEDs.
Do they mean SEC registered retail forex brokers (there are a few which are not primarily futures brokers summerstreetfx.com for instance)?

The Proposal would further require certain entities other than RFEDs and FCMs that intermediate retail forex transactions to register with the Commission as introducing brokers (“IBs”), commodity trading advisors (“CTAs”), commodity pool operators (“CPOs”), or associated persons (“APs”) of such entities, as appropriate, and to be subject to the Act and regulations applicable to that registrant category. In addition, the Proposal would require any IB that introduces retail forex transactions to an RFED or FCM to be guaranteed by that RFED or FCM.
Ouch.

The Proposal would also implement the $20 million minimum net capital standard established in the CRA for registering as an RFED or offering retail forex transactions as an FCM; propose an additional volume-based minimum capital threshold calculated on the amount an FCM or RFED owes as counterparty to retail forex transactions.
So where do US brokers go from here? Offshore.

--- 帖子 #916 ---
Here is a letter I sent to my Senators from Florida. You may want to send letters to your Senators. Time to get involved guys, but probably too late.

Senator Bill Nelson

Washington, D.C.

United States Senate

716 Senate Hart Office Building

Washington, DC 20510

Senator George LeMieux

United States Senate

356 Russell Senate Office Building

Washington, DC 20510

Dear Senator,

I have been a Forex trader for 3 years now. Even though my winnings have been modest I have enjoyed being a trader. However, due to new regulations Forex dealers and small time traders like myself are being forced out of the market. Please read the following and understand I am tired of govt. regulators joining forces with big time companies and wiping out the little guy. Please read the following story and let me know if there is anything that can be done. Otherwise I have to do my trading overseas in England or Australia where they dont punish the little guy. Why export more business and jobs when we need them here in the USA. I consider these men dangerous to this industry and they only want a small group of traders and companies to enjoy trading.

Goodbye US Forex industry

* Posted by Michael Greenberg in Brokers, Traders

So what do you when someone is constantly bullying and harassing you at your neighbourhood? Do you call the police, try to take a stand yourself or just run? Well, sometimes when nothing else helps and the situation is escalating, and this has been going on for ages it’s better just to find a new home. You tried your best and it’s not surrendering rather it’s an understanding that if someone powerful doesn’t want you there you can find better places where you can have your old quality of life back.

And my US Forex trading friends, the CFTC doesn’t want you there.

It doesn’t want you trading Forex with the US brokers who will gradually shift their operations to offshore locations where the regulator doesn’t have a conflict of interest or a powerful futures lobby forcing it to make all the wrong decisions.

Latest from CFTC is that it is “seeking public comment” on proposed leverage reduction to 10-to-1. We all know what this means: the rule is all but finalized and they just let you feel as if you are important to their decision making process. Whether you are a large broker or a small time retail trader, this will probably make no difference to these guys with a very clear agenda.

Now, I’m sure i’ll surprise you here but I’m actually a fan of a lower leverage. HOWEVER, I don’t think it should be forced on ALL forex traders. High leverage is a number one reason that newbie forex traders lose all their money. However, many professional traders as well as money managers, hedge funds, etc use high leverage in order to achieve better returns or just because their strategies require that. Some also use high leverage in order to cheaply hedge their exposure in other forex transactions.

(These are my comments not the authors. I disagree with the author on this point. High leverage is the best way to learn this industry. WHY? Because I risk less money to learn. For example, If I use 500 dollars at 400:1 leverage. My maximum loss would be 500 dollars. I will need to risk 2000 dollars to trade the same way at 100:1. My maximum loss would be 2000 dollars. With the new laws I will need to risk 20,000 at 10:1. When you are learning to be a trader which is better for you. Risk 500 dollars or 20K. This is obvious. Leverage is not my enemy it is my friend and the friend of every new trader. It allows us to lose small sums of money in the hopes of one day learning to trade larger sums. I would never have wanted to learn to trade FOREX if my minimum investment was 20K dollars. However, learning at 500 dollars was worth the price of training. The men who are writing the regulations are not protecting the small time investor they are killing them so that only a few big boys can trade. This is not an American concept. I want the freedom to trade, to learn, to lose or gain money in a free and open market. These regulators are not protecting the small investor they are wiping them out so only a privileged few can trade. Please protect my freedom to trade as I wish. I wish to trade with USA brokers but if govt. regulators wipe them out then I will be forced to use a foreign broker.)

Limiting leverage to novice traders is a great thing. Limiting leverage to ALL traders is horrible. I would recommend the CFTC to differentiate in their requirements and instead of imposing rules on all traders as if they were all identical set some kind of proficiency/experience test which will determine whether the trader can you use the leverage of his choice or be subject to a low leverage. Such test can be that trader’s testament to years of experience in trading or something of this nature.

I’ll send them this note, but I doubt it’ll make any difference. If anyone else would like to comment on that they are welcomed to send a note to: secretary@cftc.gov with “Regulation of Retail Forex” as the subject line. People, be nice or they will just throw your emails to garbage and ignore all other more balanced emails.

CFTC also oversees the vast Futures industry where many high leveraged products are present. Some are as leveraged as the spot forex right now. So why are these products aren’t limited to 10-to-1 leverage ratio? Why is it only the spot forex that is dealt with regulatory blows over and over again?

CFTC should have long time ago required all brokers to switch to ECN trading model and reduce leverage to novice traders. That’s it. That would have been so much better to the whole US forex industry, but I guess CFTC has it’s own considerations here…

Unfortunately as far as I know other regulators like FSA (UK) and FINMA (Switzerland) may take a similar approach as they look to work closely with the CFTC/NFA. Let’s hope they don’t but time will tell.

So my US forex friends, I suggest you don’t wait 60 days till the comment period is over or till the requirements are imposed – and they will be imposed as-is, find yourself a nice cosy offshore home and forget about all the problems you had at your old place.

Sincerely,

Robert Villmow

The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.

I closed that one out last Friday night. I dont always follow my own advice though. Over time when you get 2 or 3 levels deep you will learn to take that small loss. There are plenty of opportunities in the future plus it allows you to get a better entrance later. With the spike up today I hope to later get a good entrance on the GBP/USD. --- 帖子 #926 ---
Next time have a plan for your exit. I just am going to use your exit as an example. If you use the S/R indicator on a daily chart you will see that priced stopped right at a major S/R line on the  daily. The plan should have been, if price breaks this S/R line on the daily then exit. If it bounces off look for my best exit for the trade. I would have put a sell here to minimize my lose if it bounced and exit some point above if price kept going. You will learn in trading to minimize losses playing off of these major S/R lines. Notice the Daily chart below. You can see the blue line I drew showing two major S/R spots in the past. I put white arrow pointing to them. If price breaks that point your plan would be to exit. If price bounces your plan is to take the sell and reduce my loss. Once you get the hang of using S/R lines you can increase your profits and decrease your losses more. I hope this is a help to you. Next time plan where you want to take your loss, dont do it at the R line, do it after it is clearly broken. Look for the bounce and see if you get it, many times you will get it.

--- 帖子 #927 ---
Thanks for the advice - looks great. I'm working on using the s/r lines some more, they are great places to place trades/get out etc, esp when combined with the indicators. Aside from that bad trade, I'm going pretty well using the system. Just need more experience managing trades...this will come with time!

--- 帖子 #931 ---
USD/JPY. Do I ride the trade or TP. That is always the question when you come to a S/R line. Blue and White are at the top but good news last night for the USA so it could continue. What do you do? I have been straddle trading these trades. I take my maximum profit at the R line and then put a pending order buy on the other side. I also put a pending order buy at its previous S line in case we have a double bottom. So here is a pic of my trade and set up. I get tired of losing these small 20-50 pip profits because I think price will continue but they dont. So now I take them and use the pending order to follow the trade in case price does continue. I used orange arrows to show previous S/R lines. Strong enough to  close the trade for TP but knowing price may continue.

--- 帖子 #932 ---
There are several things about FOREX, theories I have developed about why price moves back and forth.

1. FOREX is NOT about traders. It was set up so businesses could trade world wide and banks are needed to exchange currencies. Most of the action comes from business and government transactions. As trade flows in one direction, sooner or later it has to also flow back.

2. When banks do transactions I believe the do all the buys first then the sells or visa versa. So price will move one way and then reverse. This is the cause of Monday gaps as banks process their weekend deposits and exchanges.

3. No matter what the fundamentals are if there has been a run on a currency and the banks have been selling say lots of CHF because businesses are exchanging GBP, sooner or later they need more CHF to sell their customers. So they have to buy some CHF to restock their supplies. Remember we trade in hundredths or thousandths of a penny, they exhange to the nearest penny, they make a whole lot more than we do on an exchange. So a move of 5-800 pips may not even be one penny at a bank counter but they need more CHF to make transactions with their customers so price retraces at some point.

These are some of my theories concerning FOREX and why I play the retraces. I know they are coming. S/R points are places where banks need to restock so price pauses, retraces and then continues if demand is still there. These retraces cause me to make profit or close out a trade for a minimum or zero loss. I know they have to come, banks need to balance their currency reserves. I dont know if I am right or wrong on this issue but it made sense to me on why price moves like it does. Banks needs in relation to business and government transactions is what moves the market on a daily basis.

primary trades

SELLS

Secondary trades
BUYS

SELLS aud/cad

OK my top 11 pairs and alternates:

This gives me 2 of each: aud, cad, chf, gbp, nzd,

4 of each eur, usd, jpy

aud/cad - aud/nzd this matches minor or commodity currencies together. As I have stated before minor currencies can get squashed by the larger currencies.

chf/jpy - eur/jpy - eur/usd - eur/cad - eur/nzd

gbp/jpy - gbp/usd - usd/chf - usd/jpy

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.

I no longer trade usd/sgd. It is going to 25:1 leverage, simply not worth using up that

--- 帖子 #951 ---
I've been looking at a (5)SMA,(8)SMA cross as a trigger for your EA's as opposed to the 3,3 cross.  Can I get your expertise on the changes needed in the code? This is at the end of the Buy EA.

//---- BUY MOVING AVERAGE

double    Var6 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  3, 0, MODE_LWMA, PRICE_CLOSE,  0);

double    Var7 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  3, 1, MODE_LWMA, PRICE_OPEN,  0);

Var6 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  3, 0, MODE_LWMA, PRICE_CLOSE,  0);

Var7 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  3, 1, MODE_LWMA, PRICE_OPEN,  0);

//---- lot setting and modifications

//buy order

if(  Var 6 > Var 7  )

If I make these changes(changes in bold) will the EA buy when the (5)SMA crosses up over the (8) SMA?

//---- BUY MOVING AVERAGE

double    Var6 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  5, 0, MODE_SMA, PRICE_CLOSE,  0);

double    Var7 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  8, 1, MODE_SMA, PRICE_OPEN,  0);

Var6 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  5, 0, MODE_SMA, PRICE_CLOSE,  0);

Var7 = iMA(NULL, PERIOD_H4,  8, 1, MODE_SMA, PRICE_OPEN,  0);

//---- lot setting and modifications

//buy order

if (  Var 6 > Var 7   )

thank you

--- 帖子 #954 ---
Thanks for all your input but I would like to point out, no matter what MA cross you use, you will always get a peeker trade. In other words price will cross and then uncross. The larger the numbers you use the longer it takes for price to enter and then a lot of the move could be gone. I have tried many different combos. However, doing these things will be an immense help in learning price movement and reaction and you will learn a lot by doing these things. It could be possible you may get fewer DD but you may also find out the profitable trades arent as profitable. The number of pips wont be as big. So when ever you gain in one area you will be giving something up in another.

I am working on an EA that will move the stop loss to 0 and then +10 after x amount of pips and also trades only one time and then quits. So far cant get all the pieces working and the guy working on it cant do it now. So it wont stop all the peekers but the more we eliminate the better off we will be.  Good luck.

--- 帖子 #955 ---
I know what you mean by the peeker trades. Crosses and recrosses occur often inside a 4HR candle.  Right now I'm manually testing this 5,8 cross at the close of the candle with just a 50 TP. This after red line is at extreme and price is in upper or lower 1/3 of chart. You'll still get peeker trades at candle close but far less of them. So far what I've seen is you can almost always take 50 pips with a L1(TP set for 50) or L2 (TP set for around 100) and the 5,8 gives much better entry points when a pair goes on a long run without a retrace. That said, I still like the idea your working on and hope your programer can help you soon. I'll be looking at a 5,8 cross with that idea also.

By the way, Go Markets AUS. emailed me back yesterday saying they now accept US. citizens and offer up to 500:1 leverage. I don't know if you saw my question in the broker section entitled who's offering more leverage. Was trying to figure out weither FX SOL AUS or GO MARKETS had the better deal with leverage. FX S. offers 400:1 leverage with a margin call at 0% margin level and GO M. offers 500:1 leverage with a margin call at 100% margin level. Go M. has much better spreads.

Hey nanningbob, I just want to drop in and say hello and congratulate you to this great approach!

I totally agree with your observations but still have a few questions about your recovery stuff:

You wrote that you would use the recovery system to get out of the whole positions with a small win (or small loss) and therfore increase the positions size with a level 2 entry (and level 3). As far as I see you just use always the same positions sizes and close a level 2/3 for a profit if you see some but leave the other positions open? I guess you reenter the level 2/3 positions if it goes against your direction again? So you normally don't close the complete positions (and use cost averaging)? Why not?

--- 帖子 #958 ---
In my downloads I have the same size lot philosophy but I have been using a progressive reentrance that works like this. If I originally played L1 5, L2 5, L3 5 that equals 15. Now I can play 3, 5, 8 which equals 16. This gives me smaller DD and quicker recovery. I dont need as many pips to 0 out a  position but the total amount does not change. I am finding this slightly less profitable but much easier to erase a DD. The maximum amount of positions I am in in any trade is 3. After testing various martingale philosophies, 3 positions max seemed to give me the best return of risk to reward ratio. My win percentage is over 70% and I hit my  SL of around + - 400 maybe 1-3 times a month on an average. I usually will win 1500-2500 pips a month so my monthly total always looks good. December was my one losing month but that was an extreme move I had not see before and dont expect to see that type of move again. In other words that was a very rare move of the forex to trend for 3 or more weeks without a major retracement on so many pairs at one time. Good luck trading.

--- 帖子 #967 ---

--- 帖子 #968 ---
Sorry I missed your question. This EA is run on Tick value. Here is the line in the code:

PipValue=MarketInfo(Symbol(),MODE_TICKVALUE);

I dont know how you would change this but I looked at the different mode values and if you changed this to MODE_OPEN I think this would change it to the next bar open. You test that on a demo and find out.

In other EAs you have to turn the Tick value to off and then it reads by bars. For example in another EA it has this function:

extern bool EachTickMode = True;

You would then put it to false and then the EA would operate according to the bars on the chart you are using.

My suggestion would be is to have a regular MA cross EA that does not reenter (mult-level or martingale EA) You could change the Magic number and use multiple EAs to have the multi-level effect. For example EA #1 would be .01 magic number 1; EA #2 would be .02 and magic number 2 and so on. If price enters on the first EA and then uncrosses you could then put the 2nd EA on and then it would enter a 2nd level at the new cross. A multilevel approach using MA crosses but using regular EAs. Since you would have several magic numbers at once you would need a third EA that would close all trades when PT is reached or set the PT manually or have each EA have its on PT. I will probably go to this idea when I get my new EA ready for my 4H system. It allows me to reenter off of price movement instead of a fixed number and then you could set a profit target.

Here is a universal MA cross EA I have used from time to time.

--- 帖子 #969 ---
Thanks for trying Bob but your suggestion to change the mode to OPEN doesn't work either when compiled. EA still trading before bar close. Man I wish I could program.

--- 帖子 #970 ---
OK try this then: MA set at 1, shift 0, MA method SIMPLE, and MODE to open. The MA 1 line will only move to the next candle at the open. So your logic could go like this.

Scenario #1:

If MA1 OPEN is > MA5 & MA8 Buy

OR

Scenario #2:

If MA1 OPEN is > MA5 & MA5 > MA8 BUY

That should work and then you are telling the EA to only trade at the open of the candle. This logic should work on any EA. Good Luck.

--- 帖子 #971 ---
I think you were on the right trail when you were looking at this line   PipValue=MarketInfo(Symbol(),MODE_T  ICKVALUE);

Changing TICKVALUE to OPEN didn't work but I tried changing it to CLOSE and the EA is waiting now. Will let you know for sure later.

--- 帖子 #972 ---
Actually you are right. Once that candle opens during that period it is always open so it will trade. Doing the close makes the candle wait until close before the EA works. Gee you are better than me.

I also began checking my weekly support levels and found a whole bunch of currencies right at the S line on the weekly and took the trades manually at the Weekly S line. A bunch of them are showing small profits so that is going to help. So that is my logic. You may want to take a look at all the currencies you are in or ones you may want to take. Weekly S line would be a great entrance and the start of digging myself out here. If they S/R levels dont hold I will have to take out all 4 level 1 trade of chf/jpy, eur/jpy, nzd/jpy and usd/chf. That will bring my DD to more acceptable levels and we go on. It will put me in a losing situation for the month but I can overcome those losses and still make a profit for the month. It will be around 1800 pip loss with 949 in the bank. I will have enough month left to over come a 800 pip negative so maybe it looks bad now but its not a problem that can be overcome. So playing the Weekly S/R lines and if they bounce I keep my profits. If they dont my loss is not disasterous but can be overcome. One of the things in trading is having a plan and that is my plan. I just dont close out losses without a plan of getting out. So my plan is weekly S/R lines hold, stay in, they dont hold get out.

--- 帖子 #979 ---
I am excited, I have what I have been looking for in a trade manager program:

Go to this website for explanations on how it works:
http://www.forexfactory.com/showthread.php?t=89371

In a nutshell this program will manage all or part of your trades according to what inputs you want. Some but not all of the things it does is:
Multi-purpose trade manager – instructions for use

This ea supervises open trades and offers these facilities for:

● selected individual trades;

● groups of trades linked by a common magic number or comment;

● or all trades

● Moves the stop loss at appropriate intervals – to breakeven, jumping stop, trailing stop.

● Offers the option to hide the stop from the broker; likewise the take profit.

● Close all open trades when the upl reaches a set target; this can include pending orders.

● Part-closure (50%) when the price reaches a set target.

● Hedge-trade opening for trades that are going bad.

● Equity protection: close all open trades when upl hits a specified level.

By default, all options are set to 'false', so the ea will do nothing until you choose some

In other words I can set this EA to my EAs magic number or all my trades and it will automatically move my SL up to 0 after x amount of pips, then +10 after x amount of pips and then every 50 pips (or any chosen number) it will move 50 pips. You can have  it do a MT4 trailing stop or a jump stop where it doesnt move until price moves 50 pips (or any other number) Anyway read the material, test it on a demo and let me know how it works I will be trying it out. I have had several trades, (in fact, most of my deep DD trades started quickly in profit 20-50 pips) then reversed. This program would catch the minimum profit of +10 or breakeven and then we could reenter at the next cross. This will also need an EA that trades once and quit and we have one of those. In other words if the Hopwood EA closes a trade you dont need the EA reentering on you again at that  point. So test it out and let me know.

--- 帖子 #980 ---
Here is a 3x3 cross sell and buy ea. There are both 4D and 5D versions. None of these EAs have been tried on a live or live demo account so do not live trade them until proven. But these EAs should trade one time and quit. They should not reenter once closed. You would need to turn off the EA and restart it on that currency for it to trade again. Good luck. Once we get this all working then we can work on a way to run multi-level trades.

--- 帖子 #981 ---
Thanks Bob. This addition should add some protection against those long runners that don't want to reverse. Take the small profit and wait for the stronger reversal later. Just to add my two cents, I've been looking at another way to decide when to add a L2 or L3  to a trade that goes against you. As I described in earlier posts, I like to trade this system manually with a TP set at 50. I'm entering when I'm seeing first that red, white and blue are at extremes. Price is at top or bottom 1/3 of chart and RSI(8) shows divergence. My idea of when to enter another level is wait until divergence happens a second time instead of just jumping in at a fixed 150-200 pips step. This may help keep DD smaller by trying to reenter at a spot that is more likely to see some reversal. The chart below shows an example. I waited until close of red candles to confirm divergence. First level trade was a no go but second level trade was a winner.

What it means is businesses arent doing business and that is not good no matter what the politicians are telling us. When countries are trading prices moves up and down with each major transaction but we are seeing that this is not happening. So we will try to ride this out until better days come.

--- 帖子 #991 ---
I am adding this to my chart but RSI 8 divergence looks good to me. I was taught on MACD divergence but you rarely see that on a 4H chart. RSI divergence looks like a winner though. Here is a pic. Notice A1 higher highs on price action but lower highs on RSI. B1 Double bottom on chart but higher lows on RSI. Looks good Toothman, great idea. Entrance then can be anyplace above or equal to A1 or Lower than or equal too B1. Try to enter as close to the highs or lows you can get. Not a bad idea. Or a pending order at the break in the S/R level at this point.

--- 帖子 #995 ---
Yeah, there is no such thing as a system that works all the time. There are thousands of threads started that show some system that will work for most of the time or during certain market conditions but there are none that are 100%. What I have tried to do with this system is to be honest about its shortcomings and showing how to get out of those bad periods. I have not enjoyed the great success since about mid December and that is because we are getting these long unretracing or minimum retracing trends. To me if I can pass these tests without major damage or breakeven to my account then I have the system down pretty good. Once again just like yesterday I am sitting on a bunch of 40-50 pip profits and I wonder, do I take them or will price finally break? I mean I could bank another 200+ pips now or do I let them ride. This is really difficult decision to make when the market just isnt reversing now. Yet I need a good move to get out of my jam. I need several currencies to do 150-250 pip runs which usually are not hard to get but recently its been tough. I dont think I have pocketed very many 100 pip runs lately and usually you get quite a few in a months time. Well we will see what happens.

--- 帖子 #1000 ---
Here is a pic of the eur/jpy trade that was so much trouble. After watching these kind of trends, I have come up with a way to handle them and will publish my ver 3 hopefully this weekend. I found a way to pick up the trade at all the orange arrows and you are going to love it. Demo the EAs etc now making sure everything works. Anyway a trend trader will be jumping up and down saying follow the trend, follow the trend. The problem is when did the trend start? How long will it last? and when and where should you get out or get in? In my pic I made a critical decision that the trend would continue once it passed the 50MA (white arrow). Well it didnt and I ended up with a big DD. I could have exited my trades there (eur/jpy, chf/jpy, nzd/jpy) for small losses. Instead I stayed in (followed the new trend ??) and got into trouble. I am again at this decision point and this time I closed out the trade. A trend trader has to decide to continue following the trend, but which way? Follow it up if it breaks the 50MA or play the bounce and follow the trend?? Tomorrow all over the world so called trend trader gurus will say didnt I tell you to follow the trend, see how it broke the 50MA and continued. See the H&S on the bottom and how it broke the previous swing high. You need to get in. OR See how price bounced of off the 50 MA and continued on the trend. Sell the rallies, how many times do I have to say sell the rallies. So what is it trend traders? answer me this? Is this a sell the rally for the DT will continue or buy the new trend, it broke the previous highs and has the candle and chart pattern buy, buy, buy or Get the picture. (see the aqua arrow) tomorrow they will have the answer. I want the answer today. My viewpoint is I stay out of the middle of the charts, dont know what will happen there.

Alternatives: the aud/jpy, eur/jpy, are all similiar so choose one. The Aud/jpy is not as volatile as the gbp/jpy if you want less movement but still like some volatility but it will do long trends more. The most important thing is you dont want to be heavily investment into any one currency. If the EUR/NZD is too volatile for your tastes you can replace it with nzd/chf or nzd/jpy. I just happen to like the eur/nzd pair and the way it flies around the chart.

Most volatile pairs: eur/nzd and gbp/jpy can be replaced with aud/jpy nzd/jpy nzd/chf for less volatility.

--- 帖子 #1008 ---
Here is a pic of what the new Ver. 3 will look like. I have a new indicator which is the red line high and red line low. The EA only enters when price breaks that line, so I think we have made a superior entrance point. Even if price goes against you for a while it wont for long. Had some real nice profits on the demo tests. Also added Hopwoods trade manager program. It will bring your SL to break even and then that eliminates suprise DD and peeker trades that sometimes happened with 3x3 cross, actually all MA crosses have this problem. So here are the rules.

1. New indicator #1 divides the screen into fourths (bold gold lines). We trade in the top and bottom 25%. Sell EA used only above this line. Buy EA used below this line. The EA only enters when price goes above this line by 1 pip. Gets you really a really good entrance I think. Shouldnt be much DD.

2. R,W,B lines near the top or bottom of the screen, also taking secondary trades.

3. RSI is above the 30 or below 70. Rule 3B. May always take trades above 90 or 10 RSI. I changed the 8 RSI to a 5. The position of the RSI doesnt change but the lines are more definitive. I have the old RSI 8 in  dotted lines for comparison.

4. Rule 4 is when we see divergance on the RSI, you can take half profit and go for the run up/down in price. You will put a 45 degree angle line on the RSI and stay in the trade until the RSI crosses that line. This is seen on trades 2 and 4. If you did this with the others it would not work as well.

5. Sell the Rallies, buy the dips. Trade 5 is a rally that came back to the gold line and we take that trade. Not sure how to explain it but we can call it a tertiary trade. Price pulls back up to an old S line so we take it if the EA will.

SO here are the trade scenarios.

1. secondary trade

2. Primary trade also divergance. Draw 45 degree line on RSI and go for the big pip move. Take half profit and let it ride till you cross the 45 degree line on RSI.

3. Same as #1

4. Same as #2, this time the RSI ride is a very good one. We actually stay in this trade for 3 days. We took half earlier and we are now riding the trade down.

5. Tertiary trade price bounces back up to an old S line so we take it as it nears the gold line and Old S line. If price doesnt break that red line we are not in.  If we get in and price goes against up we are at the top of the chart.

6. With a break in the 45 degree line and divergance on RSi we now go to a buy. This trade probably hit our break even for no pips.

7. Primary trade- off of divergance and probably trade 6 didnt get us much so 7 is another entrance.

After trade 7 there may be some secondary trades.

That is what I am trying to put together but I need to fine tune it and make sure everything is working. Will try to post it Tues or Wed. unless I come across another problem. Enjoy the pic.

--- 帖子 #1009 ---
In the above pic I think you can see that the vast majority of the time that new red line indicator gets you close to the new S/R line. When price gets in range, turn the EA on and let it handle the entrance. I will have several buy and sell EAs. One with a no take profit and one with a take profit. There will be second level and third level reentrance EAs but they will have there own Magic numbers and will be handled by the Hopwood Trade Manager. So to do multi level trading you will need to turn on the 2nd EA. Hopefully that will be a rare event now. There will be a Hopewood trade manager for each magic number.

The trade manager would already have set the trade to break even so I would never go into a negative trade at this point. From the original entrance the trade would have gone 80+ pips to the good at one point and sits around 20+ now. Either way I am sitting on a winning trade. So that is what we are looking at if I can finish this off Monday or Tuesday. Here is a pic of the Ver 3. trade. Obviosly if price had not spiked up a second time we would not be in the trade under ver.3 but we are in ver. 2 so there are trade offs between the systems. Want you to know both sides.

I just noticed that my ask line and the indicator line are the same color. I will have to change that before I put the final product up so dont let that confuse you on my example. I am not talking about the red ask line going all the way across the screen but the read line up near the blue line.

When I write the rules you will not want to turn the EA during the strong move from the grey candle crossing the gold line but would want to wait for the next candle to let price settle a bit. You would get in too early if you did even though that entrance would still be better than the ver. 2 entrance.

--- 帖子 #1028 ---
Hello mates, Long time no see since I am not posting for a while.

It sounds great to introduce divergence concept in counter trend trading. But should the line be drawm with the close instead of high or low, because RSI is cacluated base off the close price?

--- 帖子 #1029 ---
It shouldnt make any difference because you will see the divergance and have the EA on. When it enters the trade you will monitor it. I have seen  pics with RSI in which you will get 3 or 4 divergances before you get the real change of direction. In this system 5 things will happen:

1: The MPTM will bring your SL to breakeven, price reverses on you and you have a zero trade.

2. Price will move to the TP of the EA and close out that trade then the EA waits for the next entrance point.

3. You are using the jump SL which I will start at 25. So at +25 you are at 0 50 it moves the SL to +25, 75 it moves to  +50 and so on until price reverses and you have profit.

4. Price never gets to the +20 so you have a negative trade in which we start looking for a second entrance and we multi-level trade like we did in the past.

5. Price went in your favor, on divergance we play the long run so we profit 1/2 at some point and then close out the other half when RSI crosses a 45% angle which we will draw on the chart. So whether divergance is at the open or close does not matter. We only want to see it.

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

I suggest to use MACD double cross(down cross, up cross then down cross) above zero line to indicate the trend change to bearlish.  Or MACD double cross (up cross, down cross and up cross) below zero line to indicate the trend change to bullish and trigger the position.   Just some fresh thoughts.

--- 帖子 #1053 ---
I am not sure quite what you are saying. Before we discuss we need to define divergence. Divergence is when the lowest lows of the candles which you have drawn a line on the chart forming a line pointing downward. Then you connect the lowest lows on the RSI which you have drawn on the chart but that line is angling upward over the same time period. That would be divergence. The lines are going in opposite directions. With that definition you have drawn divergence in your picture. When I talk about divergence that is what I mean. I guess there are other definitions but I assume that is the most common one.

In counter trend trading we are not necessarily looking for a complete price reversal as we are just a retracement. If price has dropped 200 pips or more and now is retracing we get that trade. The divergence may not necessarily point out a true price reversal as it would a correction. This may sound crazy to people who have been trend trading but I find trading retracements easier to trade than a trend. If you are a channel trader to me it is easier to go from the outside of the channel in than inside out. If I am on the very outside it is extremely rare for price to go even more higher without retracing first. If I am on the inside of the channel hoping it will continue going up I feel I am in a guessing crapshoot. Maybe it will, probably it wont or it will fake or ....... But outside in I feel I have a much better chance, I know price will go back to a median but once it gets back I dont know if it will go up or down.

--- 帖子 #1055 ---
Here a first version of the meter-indicators.

I think that the meter-signal indicator is very usefull for analysis, because at a glance you can see all the last signals and analyze them. You can switch the drawing of arrows or vertical lines.

Just a question: are you using the fractal lines? For my eyes are to many lines in a chart...

The indicators they may have bugs, especially for the last candle...

A problem to solve was to scale the MACD and to get right values if you scroll the chart and I had not the time to test all possibilities. On scrolling you must wait few seconds until the MACD and the signals are recalculated.

Also is possible that the indicators repaints, and in this case is better to change the time frame and go back for an indicators refreshing.

Later when the indicators are tested, I can post the source codes.

I think that for a next version might be good to filter the signals for close positions above/below the two 25% lines, but first you must test this.

.

--- 帖子 #1056 ---
Please reload from my last post the NB Meter_Signals file.

Now gives the option to filter the prices above or below the 25% lines.

The condition is not strong, that means that the program check if the High is above the upper line, or the Low is below the lower line. A strong condition would be to check the Close positions.

HI Bob

Please find attached additional tool for your arsenal of indicators. It was provided by Scooby Doo and it displays RSI over all time frames. Please read the short PDF for the settings. You quite rightly mentioned that a trade can be made by relying on RSI alone. As an extra filter and additional protection some people only rely on RSI if the time frames on both side indicate the same conditions (e.g. if H1 showing O/S, then H4 and M30 should show O/S in order for entering a BUY trade).
