--- 帖子 #1925 ---
Here are some of my views on EAs so you can better understand where I come from at times. A debate on another thread.

That's a very limited view. An EA can use time, open of sessions, breakouts, key levels which are not at all indicators.

Time, so let me ask you, you enter at 300 every day? Time may determine when you want your EA to turn on or off but it does not determine how you enter a trade. If you say I do a buy every day at 300 on the EUR/USD no one would take your method seriously. It is not an indicator used to determine your entrance or exit. Same with open sessions, what do you have an EA that says do a sell every day on the GBP USD at the beginning of the USA session?? No one would take that seriously either Again it does not determine entrances or exits only when you want the EA to come on or off. It is an irrelevant to the debate.

Breakouts would be based on previous highs and lows based on some indicator. If the present high is greater then the previous candle high (attach any time frame I dont care) could be written in the code as this: if Bid is greater than the 1 Moving Average High of the previous candle then enter a buy. That is one way an EA is coded to do that trade. If your criteria is different than that, it still takes some form of MA indicator to enter the trade. So you didnt understand how you would even code the EA to do that entrance.

Key levels are all determined by where groups of candles meet. I already told you how Pivots, Fibs are coded. Obviously you dont understand how those lines are determined in a programming code. When a programmer codes an EA, indicator, etc. there are determining factors which you have to write to make the event happen. Those factors are determined by MA averages and/or math formulas of those MA. That is how an EA is written. Those lines, bars, candles, etc. you see on the screen that move with time like MA, STO, MACD, etc. use MA in the code to determine their lines, bars, candles, etc. OR they fix those lines in time like Pivots, Fibs, etc. and they are set on the screen for a time period until enough new info comes in to change them. With FIbs its a newer high or low, with pivots its a new time period. That is how they are coded in an EA. You may not understand the guts of how an EA works but that is how a programmer has to look at it. What causes an EA to enter or exit a trade, some kind of math formula based on some kind of input of averages. That is how they work. Once you fix those in a code then the weaknesses of that coding procedure or formula will then pop up over time. So all EAs will have a weakness and can be beaten under certain market conditions. Some things just can not be coded.

So do I use EAs, yes, am I successful with them, yes, but I only use them under certain market conditions and turn them off when those conditions are not met. There are some things that just cannot be coded into a formula. That is the weakness of any and all EA systems. The key to successfully using EAs is to know their weaknesses and then deal with them and let the successful part just run. However, if you dont want to understand or acknowledge their weaknesses you will never be successful with them. That is my point. http://cdn.forexfactory.com/images/s.../yim/happy.gif

Another fallacy. The lagging indicators are derivatives of price. There are leading indicators, like fibs or S/R, which have nothing to do with averages.

You need to read a good article on how FIBS are designed. They are a math formula of a previous high and low on a high TF, that is a fact. The Math formula is an average of the points in between and then fixed in time. That is what a MA is. A math formula of previous information. A 5 MA is a math formula of the last 5 bars. A 10MA is math formula of the last 10 bars. A Fib is a math formula of the previous high compared to the previous low over a certain time period. That high and low is then entered into a math formula and the average is plotted on the screen as a line. The 23.6 line is a 23.6 % average of the high and low. The 50 line is a 50% average and so on. Those lines will change depending on the TF you use. I am not a fib guy once you understand what makes it work you realize it is nothing and has nothing to do with price or the future.

S/R are based on several different types of indicators. Some take the previous highs and lows that gather in a certain area and average them out to form a Support or Resistance line. (did you see the word average again). Others can be based on an indicator (which is designed on some math formula based on averages) and then draws a line. (Fractal S/R) Fractals are based on a math formula and draws a nice little dot or arrow on your screen when that math formula is met. When you are a programmer to make things work you have to come up with Math formulas and averages to do them. That is why my statement stands as stated. To write an EA you have to use indicators that are based on MA averages to make them work. Nothing you have said changes that statement.

--- 帖子 #1936 ---
NB, great job with version 5, adding BB to sixths is a simple stroke of genius.

few observations.

1- you can remove the following code to remove the invisible black line from sixths indi.

ObjectCreate("threesixth",1,0,TimeCurrent(),High[120]);

ObjectSet("threesixth",OBJPROP_COLOR,Black);

ObjectSet("threesixth",OBJPROP_STYLE,STYLE_SOLID);

ObjectSet("threesixth",OBJPROP_WIDTH,2);

2- try testing with the bbsqueeze indi, combining with the sixths, it gives a great hint regarding the direction of the price break. When the bands are squeezed markets are ready for a huge move, but it is very hard to tell which direction the market is going to break, usually there is a initial fake out ...

For me this is the greatest benefit of this system.

3- 4D mptm files need to be placed in proper folder.

Thank you sir for a wonderful effort.

--- 帖子 #1943 ---
I wanted to stop by to tell you how good your system is !

You have developped a fantastic trading system, outstanding!

Having developped the "Trade Signals" indicator over this week-end with Steve, based on your V5 doc, I wanted to have your input on some questions i have been asking myself while working on it:

- what do you think about the "StochasticMACD" line that i coded to allow the MACD to directly compare with the 15/85 stochastic limits ?

It behaves a bit differently than the MACD line itself when you plot both on the same window, due to the automatic "refocus" that MT4 applies to keep the MACD line in the window.

The StochasticMACD will not have this refocus issue as it is normalized to 0..100 range, which was the whole idea of developping it.

However, the MACD line will change aspect if you scroll the screen left and right, which makes the decision to determine if it is "over the 85 stoch line" or "below the 15 stoch line" quite unreliable sometimes, as the MACD may well appear to be in >85 or <15 zone at some point, and then later on appear on the no-trading zone for the SAME candle.

How do you address this issue ?

On the other hand, the StochasticMACD line will get "saturated" earlier, which is the classic flaw of all stachastic oscillators.

The line looks quite distorted sometimes compared to the MACD itself.

Thanks for your time.

SQ

--- 帖子 #1944 ---
First thank you for your work and contributions. They are appreciated very much. The sto/macd was designed around the principle that Sto was an indicator that was too early in its signals and the MACD was too late in its signals so I put them together to get the best of both worlds. It works very well in ranging markets and fairly well in some trending markets. When those lines cross you have a very good chance of price reversal. However, like all MA based indicators they are not good in super news stories. (NFP is not a super news story, USA housing market sales dropping 30% is). Right now the market is being dominated by news stories so indicators are taking a beating. If countries start going bankrupt or need emergency loans to stay afloat or countries start moving their interest rates quickly to compensate, indicators cannot keep up with such news or accurately report what is happening until it is too late.

Anyway I have used this indicator for years and am used to its nuances. Now fixing the MACD like Sto will be interesting to look at and I will do that. I have final exams this week at the university I am teaching at, finishing with grades and then I will give this my 100% undivided attention. Meanwhile I put the first section out early so I could benefit from the wisdom of traders and programmers like you and others. I want to fine tune this into a consistent system. I can already tell you where my concentration is going to be. It is going to be on the outer bands of the BB. How does a 1,2, or 3 MA median interact with it and does it give us a clue whether it will bounce off of the bands or will it run up the bands. If it does it solves the conundrum of BB, ie. will price bounce off of the bands or will it run up/down the band. Even if it filters out 50% of the runners that is 50% we dont have to deal with in DD. The other side of my contribution will be when price does come back inside the BB outer bands how will we trade it? Those are the areas I want to put my attention to. The other areas, if guys like you can improve, I am all for it. So yes that is what I wish for.

Hi BOB

IMHO profitability of the system is quite satisfactory and the way to improve this further is to reduce DD. It may be stating the obvious and judging by your writings, I believe this is your opinion as well.

As you may recall in May a few of my fellow traders and I had large DD problem with NZD pairs. At present we have the same problem with CHF pairs. As a result of this I planning to try to avoid entering into trades with similar correlation in future (e.g. if trading AUDCHF would avoid trading CADCHF or NZDCHF). Needless to say by doing this if the trades are +ve there will be less profit but with -ve trades there will be less DD. I would like to have your thoughts regarding this idea.

Kind Regards

--- 帖子 #1947 ---
There are two ways of doing this. The way I do it is I trade all of them but in very small amounts, nickels or dimes. Sometimes the DD may seem like a large number but money wise it amounts to several hundred dollars. Not enough to break me. If you choose only one you probably then would go with higher lot sizes. Now pip wise it may seem smaller DD but money wise you probably will see the same. The reason I do all of them is I dont know which ones will move a lot and which ones will move a little. I may get 25 pips on nzd/usd and 75 on nzd/chf and the next day nzd/usd may go 50 and nzd/chf 10. Or worse yet nzd/usd will go +40 and nzd/chf -75. So that is why I play most of them.

Again we are not in a normal market, it is very news driven and very very difficult to trade. We always want to make improvements but DD is part of the business or taking a SL is part of the business. Those are your choices.

One of the things about versoin 5 is BB entrances give you an extra 40-80 pip better entrance than an MA cross but the MA cross helped keep you out of the trades on BB runs. You sacrifice one advantage to take advantage of another. To me the 6ths indicator gives the advantage back to BB. We use it to help filter out some of these runs but it wont eliminate all of them.

The second part of version 5 is I am going to 2 levels instead of three. When  price runs up the band and you use the #2 EA to enter when price comes back inside. Rarely if ever will price do another BB run. It is a rare event so the 2nd L should get you out of trouble and close to break even most of the time. I am not even going to put a third level EA in the system. If you want a third level you will need to add that yourself by going into the EA changing the magic number and lot size. So that is how the vision is developing. 2.4.2 recovery is going to become 1.2. ???

--- 帖子 #1953 ---
Bob, I have been demo-ing your system and while it is AMAZING, (respect to all your hard work) - I'm still frightened by the level 2, level 3 drawdown component. The tweak I have been considering to overcome that is to initially trade the runners until they reverse, rather than to expect them all to immediately reverse.  Your system absolutely nails the point at which we should consider trading either a reversal or continuation of a trend and that is its great strength.

Adopting a trade the trend before the reversal approach will solve the problem of super news stories as well, because you will be in the trade in the right direction while it happens until the reversal, at which point you would stop and reverse your trade.

Basically - price in the right sixths range, and moving outside the BBs, with MACD and Stochs lined up - then start with a trade in the direction of the current trend, then stop and reverse the trade when your EA would enter for the reversal trade.

If you are working with Steve Hopwood on a refined EA, please consider adding this variant (without or without your 2 4 2,  3 level system), because i think it would remove the one weakness of your system.

If you want to discuss further feel free to PM me.

regards

f451

--- 帖子 #1956 ---
What I'm suggesting is that when price crosses the BB initially enter in the direction of the trend UNTIL your EA enters for the reversal. At that point close the with trend trade, and enter the reversal trade. So you would have a series of short trades at each of the ticks you have marked on the chart, which close when your EA enters under the reversal conditions, and you would capture the long runner that one time in 12.

cheers

f451

--- 帖子 #1977 ---
This is called the bomb EA. It is designed only for brokers that allow hedgeing. It hedges all trades that are over -100 pips in the hole and allow winning trades to run. It is designed to protect your account if a sudden disaster news story hits. For example some country filing for bankruptcy and the markets go nuts. You just turn on this MTPM and the negative trades are hedged and the winners are allowed to run. Hopefully you will have enough winning trads to over come the hedged trades. Only for emergencies but I need it tested on some demo accounts. Just put it on a demo with a bunch of trades and see if they hedge at -100. Thanks.

--- 帖子 #1980 ---
Hi

i coded a variant of the Sixths Lines indicator, that you may find useful.

It draws the classic Sixths Lines: Gold and Green Lines, but also plots additional Blue Lines at the price extreme points (Sixths levels 0 and 6 in fact).

However, instead of plotting the lines as horizontal lines, which have no left/right limits, it plots trendlines, limited on the left to BarCount bars, so this shows what is the price period actually used to determine all Sitxhs lines, and it will also plot dashed lines for extensions of the Sixths lines in the "future", where the "present" is materialized by a vertical dot line that i called the "SixthAnchorTime" line.

As you will see, it plots this "SixthAnchorTime" line at roughly 4/5th of the screen time extent, so you can actually see the "future lines"on the right side.

These lines will track scrolling actions (at every new tick, though).

This allows to scroll along the chart and have the Sixths lines and Future lines updated to fit the part of the chart you are looking at.

This is nothing new, it is already in previous versions of the Indi; but i thought it would be worth mensionning, as you may feel like it is not updating sometimùes, but that's only because there is no new tick to "kick" the indicator...

So, over the week-end, it will simply NOT track your moves -- you'll have to kick it "manually" (ctrl-I, Edit, OK, Close).

You can zoom-in or zoom-out, the lines will keep their values based on the BarCount.

Here is 2 examples, with and without zooming-in;

"classic" zoom (~4 weeks of H4 bars on chart):
Attached Image (click to enlarge)

zoomed-out:
Attached Image (click to enlarge)

SQ

--- 帖子 #1981 ---
Just out of curiosity...

I've been playing with the Sixths Lines Indicator and the derived "Trade Direction Finder" indicator that we wrote with Steve (available on Steve's thread here: http://www.forexfactory.com/showpost.php?p=3849813 )

Looking at how the Sixths Lines are drawn, I noticed that it would just be another form of Stochastic oscillator...

Here is the thing:

the Sixths lines devide the screen into 6 identical price areas, taking the highest and lowest as extreme prices.

The "gold lines" are at 1/6 and 5/6 of price extent over the "screen duration".

The "screen duration" is approx. 120 bars, if we follow Bob's doc

-- ~4 weeks of H4 chart, that's 4*5*24/4 = 120 H4-bars.

We take as part of the trade signal the fact that price should be above(resp below) the higher(resp lower) gold line.

These lines are the result of the last ~120 bars price action.

And the gold lines are drawn at 16%(~1/6) and 84%(~5/6) of the price extent over these ~120 bars.

To me, this is quite the same as taking the STOCHASTIC(120bars) of the price line, and consider the 16 and 84 levels as the gold lines.

Try drawing a stochastic(120) (set %K=120, %D=1 and Slowing=1, and just show the main line).

You will clearly see that price crosses Sixths gold lines exactly when the stochastic(120) crosses the 16/84 levels.

Here is an example:

Attached Image (click to enlarge)

I also attached a template that will load the Sixth "future" indi and the sto(120).

SQ

--- 帖子 #1982 ---
The sixth line is based on the height of the chart. It is based on whatever formula MT4 is using for its screens. I do not know that formula. Other indicators (pivots, Fib. etc) use the previous high/low of price but the 6ths uses the high and low of the chart screen plus added distance to make the screen visually appealing. So it is the high and low of price action plus adding space above/below these two points based on the volatility of the pair being used.

The indicator is interesting you have created but is there a way to make it more visually appealing like the line crossing in the middle of the indicator rather than near the bottom?? That would make it easy to read and if we called that a 50 line the rule would be simple cross the 50 line up buy, cross the 50 line down sell, set TP just short of the next line, set SL just above the line you crossed. That indi could be an interesting development. Good work.

--- 帖子 #1983 ---
Hi Bob,

Are you talking about the green stochastic oscillator in the bottom part of the screenshot ?

That's just a regular Stochastic indicator, just like your blue and white stochastics in your docs, with the settings i mentionned (%K=120, %D=1, Smoothing=1, no color for signal line), along with 2 lines levels set to 16 and 84 -- that's probably close enough to the 15/85 of the white/blue stochastic to have this sto(120) plotted on the SAME sub-window actually...

If you're talking about the "Sixths Future" indi, then i have no way of making lines plot anywhere else than where the price line drives it.

In "standard V5 zoom" (4 weeks of H4 bars on the screen, first screenshot), then it is exactly the same as the previous Sixths indis, with the Blue lines in addition (and future dashed lines).

When zoomed out, these will be drawn wherever price is.

Perhaps i misunderstood your question ?

Please clarify if this is the case.

As for entering + setting the TP and SL levels, we could very well use the Gold line crossback on retrace to enter the trade (this idea was sent to me by PM lately) and use the next green line as TP and Blue as SL.

This gives us a somewhat "decent" constant R:R ratio of 1.

I have volontarily let the BB plotted too in the template, so we can see how price moves towards the opposite BB after the retrace, and see where price crosses first the green line, or the BB.

We could exit the trade when price hits the opposite BB, or the green line, whichever comes first.

If price does not retrace enough to cross the green line, then it will surely hit the BB because BB will narrow down as price action is slowing.

We could use the same for SL rule: hit blue line, or hit the opposite BB, whichever comes first -- yes, the same opposite BB as for TP rule: if price turns around after a small retrace only (we had a false signal), then the BB will continue in the same initial direction (trend continuation), and the opposite BB (down BB for a sell at high gold line) will cross price quite quickly, and probably not too far against us.

This is just my observation after having played with all these indis (blue stochs + stochastic MACD, and the moving SixthsFuture lines) for several days now.

I'm eeger to read your next (exit) rules chapters !

SQ

--- 帖子 #1984 ---
Here is the Indicator that Steve Hopwood and I developped last week for the NNBv5 system.

We initially posted an earlier version of this indicator in "Steve Hopwood's Fib Target-level retracement auto-trader: compliments Simon" thread).

Here is the "User's guide":

- put the .mq4 in your (MT4-platform)/experts/indicators folder;

- compile it, or close+restart MT4 to have it compiled;

- Recommended Chart is H4 (although it will give (different)signals on other TF).

It plots ENTRY SIGNAL ARROWS when NNBv5 system entry conditions are met;

It draws an "EXIT Line" showing the typical exit levels;

It draws the "SixthsFuture" Lines, as in Squalou's "SIXTHS SQ.mq4" indicator, so you won't need to load this Indi manually;

- ENTRY signals:

- price is beyond NNB's "Sixths Lines" Indicator's Gold Line (upper Gold for SELL, lower Gold for BUY)

- Blue Stochastic is >=85(SELL) or <=15(BUY)

- StochasticMACD (developped by Squalou) is >=85(SELL) or <=15(BUY)

This version does NOT yet use the BB25 lines in its Entry signals;

- EXIT Line:

- default is to use the NEAREST GREEN Line at the time of the FIRST signal;

AND the opposite BB25 line ("ExitOnOppositeBB=true")

- OPTIONALLY, the BB25 line can be ignored, the exit line will then be the initial Green Line alone.

This version is EXPERIMENTAL, it's purpose is to fit to Bob's system first, WHICH IS NOT YET COMPLETELY THE CASE, see how it performs visually, and find possible improvements.

It will include refinements/modifications based on Bob's and other's remarks.

I have also attached a template file (goes to (MT4)/templates folder) that will load all the NNBv5 indicators and this one as well.

You will notice that it load an extra stochastic(120) green line, with additional 33/66 green levels:

this is to illustrate one of my previous posts about the sto(120) and SixthsLines similarity:

- when price crosses the Sixths Gold line, the sto(120) will also cross the 15/85 gold levels;

- when price crosses the Sixth Green Line, the sto(120) will also cross the 33/66 Green levels;

This helps easily spot past Sixth Lines crossings on the chart without having to scroll the chart with the SixthFuture indicator loaded.

FOR THOSE WHO WANT TO USE THE INDICATOR INTO AN EA:

you can try this:

Inserted Code //UP signals:

upsignal = iCustom(NULL,0,"NNBv5 Signals - Sq and Steve's Indicator", 0/*SignalUP*/,0);
if (upsignal != EMPTY_VALUE) your_buy_code_here(...);

//DOWN signals:

downsignal = iCustom(NULL,0,"NNBv5 Signals - Sq and Steve's Indicator", 1/*SignalDN*/,0);
if (downsignal != EMPTY_VALUE) your_sell_code_here(...);
SQ
